Title: Regulations, Part I: Radiocommunication Act and Radiocommunication Regulations.

Questions.Question: Authority to make regulations governing radiocommunications is derived from:
Answers: the Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service
Questions.Explanation: Countries administer radio within their borders and territorial waters. The Canadian parliament enacted the 'Radiocommunication Act' (a law). This law grants authority to Industry Canada to regulate radio communications. That department then issues 'Radiocommunication Regulations' where services such as the "maritime service", the "aeronautical service" and the "amateur radio service" are defined.

Questions.Question: Authority to make "Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service" is derived from:
Answers: the Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service
Questions.Explanation: Countries administer radio within their borders and territorial waters. The Canadian parliament enacted the 'Radiocommunication Act' (a law). This law grants authority to Industry Canada to regulate radio communications. That department then issues 'Radiocommunication Regulations' where services such as the "maritime service", the "aeronautical service" and the "amateur radio service" are defined.

Questions.Question: The Department that is responsible for the administration of the Radiocommunication Act is:
Questions.Explanation: Transport-Canada [<1970] and Communications-Canada [1970-1993] HAVE looked after radio licences IN THE PAST. Countries administer radio within their borders and territorial waters. The Canadian parliament enacted the 'Radiocommunication Act' (a law). This law grants authority to Industry Canada to regulate radio communications. That department then issues 'Radiocommunication Regulations' where services such as the "maritime service", the "aeronautical service" and the "amateur radio service" are defined.

Questions.Question: The "amateur radio service" is defined in:
Answers: the Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service
Questions.Explanation: Countries administer radio within their borders and territorial waters. The Canadian parliament enacted the 'Radiocommunication Act' (a law). This law grants authority to Industry Canada to regulate radio communications. That department then issues 'Radiocommunication Regulations' where services such as the "maritime service", the "aeronautical service" and the "amateur radio service" are defined.

Questions.Question: What must you do to notify your mailing address changes?
Answers: Contact Industry Canada and provide details of your address change
Telephone your local club, and give them your new address
Contact an accredited Radioiner and provide details of your address change
Write amateur organizations advising them of your new address, enclosing your certificate
Questions.Explanation: Industry Canada must be notified WITHIN 30 DAYS of a change of address. (RBR-4, formerly RIC-2)

Questions.Question: An Amateur Radio Operator Certificate is valid for:
Questions.Explanation: Valid for life. No annual renewal. No yearly fees. Allows operating anywhere in Canada.

Questions.Question: Whenever a change of address is made:
Answers: within the same province, there is no need to notify Industry Canada
Industry Canada must be advised of any change in postal address
Industry Canada must be notified within 14 days of operation at the new address
the station shall not be operated until a change of address card is forwarded to Industry Canada
Questions.Explanation: Industry Canada must be notified WITHIN 30 DAYS of a change of address. (RBR-4, formerly RIC-2)

Questions.Question: The Amateur Radio Operator Certificate:
Answers: must be kept on the person to whom it is issued
must be retained at the station
must be kept in a safe place
Questions.Explanation: Station licenses used to be issued for a specific address. Keeping the Certificate at the address supplied to Industry Canada is now the norm.

Questions.Question: The holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate shall, at the request of a duly appointed radio inspector, produce the certificate, or a copy thereof, to the inspector, within ____ hours after the request:
Questions.Explanation: Holder of radio authorization has 48 HOURS to fulfill the request of a radio inspector. (Radio Regulations)

Questions.Question: The fee for an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate is:
Questions.Explanation: The initial certificate is free. There are no yearly renewals.

Questions.Question: The Amateur Radio Operator Certificate should be:
Answers: retained on the radio amateur's person
retained in the radio amateur's vehicle
retained at the address provided to Industry Canada
retained in a safety deposit box
Questions.Explanation: Station licenses used to be issued for a specific address. Keeping the Certificate at the address supplied to Industry Canada is now the norm.

Questions.Question: Out of amateur band transmissions:
Answers: must be identified with your call sign
are permitted for short tests only
are prohibited - penalties could be assessed to the control operator
Questions.Explanation: Out of band transmissions contravene the regulations of the Amateur service.

Questions.Question: If an amateur pretends there is an emergency and transmits the word "MAYDAY," what is this called?
Answers: Nothing special: "MAYDAY" has no meaning in an emergency
Questions.Explanation: This becomes a 'false or fraudulent' distress signal. It is an offence punishable under the Radiocommunication Act.

Questions.Question: A person found guilty of transmitting a false or fraudulent distress signal, or interfering with, or obstructing any radio communication, without lawful cause, may be liable, on summary conviction, to a penalty of:
Answers: a prison term of two years
a fine, not exceeding $5,000, or a prison term of one year, or both
Questions.Explanation: False distress signals and interference are punishable by a fine not exceeding $5000 or a prison term not exceeding one year OR BOTH. (Radiocommunication Act)

Questions.Question: What government document states the offences and penalties for non compliance of the rules governing radiocommunications?
Answers: The Radiocommunications Law Reform Act of 2002
The Official Radio Rules of Canada
Questions.Explanation: Key words: OFFENCES and PENALTIES. Offences and their consequences are defined when a law is enacted by government; in this case, the Radiocommunication Act.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not correct? The Minister may suspend an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate:
Answers: Where the holder has contravened the Radiocommunication Act, its Regulations, or the terms and conditions of the certificate
Where the certificate was obtained through misrepresentation
Where the holder has failed to comply with a request to pay fees or interest due
With no notice, or opportunity to make representation thereto
Questions.Explanation: The holder is always notified of a suspension or revocation. Except for failure to pay fees, license holders ARE given a chance to make representations. (Radiocommunication Act)

Questions.Question: Which of the following statements is not correct?
Answers: The person in charge of a place entered by a radio inspector shall give the inspector information that the inspector requests
A radio inspector may enter a dwelling without the consent of the occupant and without a warrant
Where entry is refused, and is necessary to perform his duties under the Act, a radio inspector may obtain a warrant
In executing a warrant, a radio inspector shall not use force, unless accompanied by a peace officer, and force is authorized
Questions.Explanation: A radio inspector may NOT enter a dwelling (house) without consent AND without a warrant. (Radiocommunication Act)

Questions.Question: What age must you be to hold an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with Basic Qualification?
Questions.Explanation: "There are no age or nationality restrictions to those who may take the Radioinations. Candidates must provide adequate photo identification to Radioiners prior to the Radioination." (RIC-3, Age and Nationality)

Questions.Question: Which Radioination must be passed before an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate is issued?
Questions.Explanation: The Basic Qualification is the only Radioination needed to obtain a Certificate ( and a call sign ).

Questions.Question: Holders of which one of the following certificates may be issued an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate?
Answers: Canadian Radiocommunication Operator General Certificate Maritime (RGMC)
Canadian Restricted Operator's Certificate - Maritime Commercial (ROC-MC)
Questions.Explanation: "Persons holding any of the following Canadian certificates may be issued an authorization to operate in the amateur radio service with the same operating privileges as the holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with Basic, Morse code and Advanced Qualifications: Radiocommunication Operator General Certificate Maritime (RGMC), ..." (RIC-3, Certificate Equivalency and RIC-16)

Questions.Question: After an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with Basic qualifications is issued, the holder may be Radioined for additional qualifications in the following order:
Answers: Morse code after passing the Basic with Honours
Morse code after passing the Advanced
Questions.Explanation: After obtaining the Basic, the Morse or Advanced qualifications can be obtained in any sequence.

Questions.Question: One Morse code qualification is available for the Amateur Radio Operator Certificate. It is:
Questions.Explanation: The 12 and 15 words per minute Morse tests have long been discontinued. [ 15 w.p.m. discontinued in the 1990 Restructuration, 12 w.p.m. discontinued in May 2001. ]

Questions.Question: The holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with the Basic Qualification is authorized to operate following stations:
Answers: a station authorized in the maritime service
any authorized station except stations authorized in the amateur, aeronautical or maritime services
a station authorized in the amateur service
a station authorized in the aeronautical service
Questions.Explanation: Holder of radio authorization must limit his activities to services specified in the license. An Amateur Certificate is valid for Amateur bands only.

Questions.Question: What conditions must candidates to amateur radio certification meet?
Answers: Be at least 14 years of age and a Canadian citizen or permanent resident
Have a valid address in Canada
Be a Canadian citizen or permanent resident
Questions.Explanation: "There are no age or nationality restrictions to those who may take the Radioinations. Candidates must provide adequate photo identification to Radioiners prior to the Radioination." (RIC-3, Age and Nationality)

Questions.Question: Radio apparatus may be installed, placed in operation, repaired or maintained by the holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with Advanced Qualification on behalf of another person:
Answers: if the transmitter of a station, for which a radio authorization is to be applied for, is type approved and crystal controlled
if the other person is the holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate to operate in the amateur radio service
pending the granting of a radio authorization, if the apparatus covers the amateur and commercial frequency bands
pending the granting of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate if the apparatus covers the amateur frequency bands only
Questions.Explanation: Installing and operating a radio station on behalf of someone else can only be done if the other person has an Amateur Certificate. Allusion to the 'Advanced' qualification is a misleading clue.

Questions.Question: The holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate may design and build from scratch transmitting equipment for use in the amateur radio service provided that person has the:
Questions.Explanation: "Advanced Qualification: all amateur bands below 30 MHz, transmitter power of 1000 watts DC input, build and operate transmitting equipment, establish repeaters and club stations. Basic Qualification: all amateur bands above 30 MHz, power of 250 watts DC input, build and operate all station equipment, except for "home-made" transmitters. "Build" in the context of the Basic Certificate is limited to the assembly of commercially available transmitter kits of professional design." (RIC-3, Privileges and Restrictions)

Questions.Question: Where a friend is not the holder of any type of radio operator certificate, you, as a holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with Basic Qualification, may, on behalf of your friend:
Answers: modify and repair the radio apparatus but not install it
not install, place in operation, modify, repair, maintain, or permit the operation of the radio apparatus
install an amateur station, but not operate or permit the operation of the apparatus
install and operate the radio apparatus, using your own call sign
Questions.Explanation: Installing or operating a station on behalf of an unlicensed person is prohibited.
Questions.Keyword: RIEND, NOT the holder of a certificate.

Questions.Question: A radio amateur with Basic and Morse code qualifications may install an amateur station for another person:
Answers: only if the other person is the holder of a valid Amateur Radio Operator Certificate
only if the final power input does not exceed 100 watts
only if the station is for use on one of the VHF bands
only if the DC power input to the final stage does not exceed 200 watts
Questions.Explanation: Installing and operating a radio station on behalf of someone else can only be done if the other person has an Amateur Certificate. Allusions to qualification, power and bands are misleading clues.

Questions.Question: Which of these statements is not correct?
Answers: An accredited volunteer Radioiner must hold an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate with Basic, Advanced, and Morse code qualifications
The fee for taking an Radioination for an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate at an Industry Canada office is $20 per qualification
The fee for taking an Radioination for an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate at an Industry Canada office is $5 per qualification
An accredited Radioiner may recover the cost of administering an Radioination
Questions.Explanation: Key words: NOT CORRECT. "The Radiocommunication Regulations prescribe a fee of $20 for each Radioination conducted by Industry Canada personnel. This fee is charged for each qualification being Radioined. Morse code sending and receiving are considered to be one Radioination. The same fees are applicable to re-Radioinations. Accredited Radioiners may not charge this fee; however, they may recover, from the candidate, the cost of administering an Radioination. There is no remittance, in whole or in part, of these costs to Industry Canada, as the Radio Regulations prescribed fee applies only to Radioinations conducted by Industry Canada staff." (RIC-1, Radioination Fees)

Questions.Question: Which of the following statements is not correct?
Answers: A disabled candidate must pass a normal amateur radio certificate Radioination before being granted any qualification
A disabled candidate, taking a Morse code sending test, may be allowed to recite the Radioination text in Morse code sounds
Radioinations for disabled candidates may be given orally, or tailored to the candidate's ability to complete the Radioination
An accredited Radioiner may recover the cost of administering an Radioination
Questions.Explanation: Key words: NOT CORRECT. "Accredited Radioiners may not exempt a candidate from the requirement for an Radioination. However, in the following specific cases, accredited Radioiners may provide accommodated testing when a candidate is unable to complete an Radioination due to a physical disability." (RIC-1, Persons with Disabilities)

Questions.Question: The fee for taking Radioinations for amateur radio operator certificates by an accredited volunteer Radioiner is:
Answers: to be negotiated between Radioiner and candidate
always $20 per visit regardless of the number of Radioinations
Questions.Explanation: "The Radiocommunication Regulations prescribe a fee of $20 for each Radioination conducted by Industry Canada personnel. This fee is charged for each qualification being Radioined. Morse code sending and receiving are considered to be one Radioination. The same fees are applicable to re-Radioinations. Accredited Radioiners may not charge this fee; however, they may recover, from the candidate, the cost of administering an Radioination. There is no remittance, in whole or in part, of these costs to Industry Canada, as the Radio Regulations prescribed fee applies only to Radioinations conducted by Industry Canada staff." (RIC-1, Radioination Fees)

Questions.Question: The fee for taking amateur radio certificate Radioinations at an Industry Canada office is:
Answers: $20 per visit, regardless of the number of qualification Radioinations
Questions.Explanation: "The Radiocommunication Regulations prescribe a fee of $20 for each Radioination conducted by Industry Canada personnel. This fee is charged for each qualification being Radioined. Morse code sending and receiving are considered to be one Radioination. The same fees are applicable to re-Radioinations. Accredited Radioiners may not charge this fee; however, they may recover, from the candidate, the cost of administering an Radioination. There is no remittance, in whole or in part, of these costs to Industry Canada, as the Radio Regulations prescribed fee applies only to Radioinations conducted by Industry Canada staff." (RIC-1, Radioination Fees)

Questions.Question: Which of the following statements is false?
Answers: A candidate who fails a written Radioination for lack of reading skills may be given an oral Radioination
A candidate who fails a written Radioination due to not usually speaking English or French may be given an oral Radioination
An Radioiner may request medical evidence from a practicing medical physician before accommodating testing
A candidate with insufficient knowledge of English or French may be accompanied by an interpreter
Questions.Explanation: "Candidates who have physical disabilities which prevent them from completing Radioinations in the normal manner should discuss their situation with their Radioiner to determine whether an accommodated testing procedure may be considered. The Radioiner may require that medical evidence from a practicing medical physician be provided. When a candidate fails a written Radioination because the language he or she normally uses is neither English nor French, or because academic limitations restrict the ability to read the questions properly, an oral Radioination may be given by the Radioiner". (RIC-3, Candidates)

Questions.Question: How much voltage does a standard automobile battery usually supply?
Questions.Explanation: Also known as a 'storage cell', the common Lead-Acid battery has a nominal voltage of 12 volts  [ 12.6 to be exact ]

Questions.Question: Which component has a positive and a negative side?
Questions.Explanation: Fuses, resistors and potentiometers are not 'polarized' (current can flow through them either way). The battery, however, has a positive terminal and a negative terminal.

Questions.Question: A cell, that can be repeatedly recharged by supplying it with electrical energy, is known as a:
Questions.Explanation: A 'storage cell' can be recharged repeatedly. A 'primary cell', such as a common Zinc-Carbon flashlight cell, can only be used once.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is a source of electromotive force (EMF)?
Questions.Explanation: EMF = Electromotive Force, synonym for voltage. Lithium-ion batteries are common in modern portable equipment.

Questions.Question: An important difference between a conventional flashlight battery and a lead acid battery is that only the lead acid battery:
Questions.Explanation: The 'conventional' Zinc-Carbon or Alkaline flashlight battery CANNOT be recharged while a 'storage cell' like a car battery can be recharged numerous times.

Questions.Question: An alkaline cell has a nominal voltage of 1.5 volts. When supplying a great deal of current, the voltage may drop to 1.2 volts. This is caused by the cell's:
Questions.Explanation: An ideal battery would supply precisely the same voltage regardless of the current drawn. Real-life batteries exhibit 'internal resistance' which causes a drop in voltage when current is drawn. Ever noticed the headlights dim when the starter is cranked on a cold winter day ?

Questions.Question: An inexpensive primary cell in use today is the carbon-zinc or flashlight cell. This type of cell can be recharged:
Questions.Explanation: The 'conventional' Zinc-Carbon or Alkaline flashlight battery CANNOT be recharged while a 'storage cell' like a car battery can be recharged numerous times.

Questions.Question: Battery capacity is commonly stated as a value of current delivered over a specified period of time. What is the effect of exceeding that specified current?
Answers: The battery will accept the subsequent charge in shorter time
The voltage delivered will be higher
A battery charge will not last as long
The internal resistance of the cell is short-circuited
Questions.Explanation: One important specification of rechargeable batteries is the 'capacity' expressed in milliampere-hour (or ampere-hour), a certain amount of current that can be delivered for a given period of time (typically, 20 hours). Exceeding the capacity reduces operating time, the battery is depleted more rapidly.

Questions.Question: To increase the current capacity of a cell, several cells should be connected in:
Questions.Explanation: A parallel combination of batteries will permit supplying more current at a given voltage.

Questions.Question: To increase the voltage output, several cells are connected in:
Questions.Explanation: Adding cells in series brings up the available voltage. However, the total current available from the string remains limited to what a single cell can supply.

Questions.Question: A lithium-ion battery should never be:
Questions.Explanation: Lithium-ion cells have very low 'internal resistance'. Hence, they can supply potentially dangerous currents in a short-circuit.

Questions.Question: How do you find a resistor's tolerance rating?
Answers: By using Thevenin's theorem for resistors
By reading the resistor's colour code
Questions.Explanation: The last band in a resistor's colour code identifies 'tolerance': an allowed variance in percentage from the nominal value. For Radiople, a GOLD band means 5%.

Questions.Question: What do the first three-colour bands on a resistor indicate?
Answers: The value of the resistor in ohms
Questions.Explanation: The first two bands are significant digits, the third band is a multiplier. The fourth band is tolerance.

Questions.Question: What would the fourth colour band on a 47 ohm resistor indicate?
Answers: The value of the resistor in ohms
Questions.Explanation: The last band in a resistor's colour code identifies 'tolerance': an allowed variance in percentage from the nominal value. For Radiople, a GOLD band means 5%.

Questions.Question: What are the possible values of a 100 ohm resistor with a 10% tolerance?
Questions.Explanation: 100 ohms minus 10% is 90 ohms, 100 ohms plus 10 % is 110 ohms.

Questions.Question: How do you find a resistor's value?
Answers: By using the resistor's colour code
By using Thevenin's theorem for resistors
Questions.Explanation: The first two bands are significant digits, the third band is a multiplier. The last band is tolerance.

Questions.Question: A club project requires that a resistive voltage divider provide a very accurate and predictable ratio. Out of the list below, which resistor tolerance would you select?
Questions.Explanation: Key words: ACCURATE and PREDICTABLE. The smallest possible "tolerance" will ensure that the actual value of the resistors fall within a narrow range of their nominal values.

Questions.Question: You need a current limiting resistor for a light-emitting diode (LED). The actual resistance is not critical at all. Out of the list below, which resistor tolerance would you select?
Questions.Explanation: Key words: NOT CRITICAL. A wide tolerance is amply acceptable when the actual value of the resistor is not critical. The extra cost of a precision resistor is not needed.

Questions.Question: If a carbon resistor's temperature is increased, what will happen to the resistance?
Answers: It will increase by 20% for every 10 degrees centigrade
It will change depending on the resistor's temperature coefficient rating
Questions.Explanation: Temperature affects all components and conductors.

Questions.Question: A gold tolerance band on a resistor indicates the tolerance is:
Questions.Explanation: 'Gold' means 5%.

Questions.Question: Which colour band would differentiate a 120-ohm from a 1200-ohm resistor?
Questions.Explanation: The first two bands are significant digits, the third band is a multiplier. The fourth band is tolerance. In this Radiople, both first bands read '1', both second bands read '2'. The third band multiplies by 10 or 100 as the case may be.

Questions.Question: Given that red=2, violet=7 and yellow=4, what is the nominal value of a resistor whose colour code reads "red", "violet" and "yellow"?
Questions.Explanation: The first two bands are significant digits, the third band is a multiplier. The fourth band is tolerance. In this Radiople, the first two digits are '27' and the multiplier adds four zeroes (or multiplies by 10,000). Result = 270,000 ohms or 270 kilohms.

Questions.Question: If an ammeter marked in amperes is used to measure a 3000 milliampere current, what reading would it show?
Questions.Explanation: Milli is a thousandth. A thousand milliamperes is one ampere. Converting from milliamperes to amperes: from small units to larger units, requires fewer digits, decimal point moves to the left by three positions, a thousand times less.

Questions.Question: If a voltmeter marked in volts is used to measure a 3500 millivolt potential, what reading would it show?
Questions.Explanation: Milli is a thousandth. A thousand millivolts is one volt. Converting from millivolts to volts: from small units to larger units, requires fewer digits, decimal point moves to the left by three positions, a thousand times less.

Questions.Question: A kilohm is:
Questions.Explanation: Kilohm is a thousand ohms. Converting from kilohm to ohms: from large units to smaller units, requires more digits, decimal point moves to the right by three positions, a thousand times more.

Questions.Question: 6.6 kilovolts is equal to:
Questions.Explanation: Kilovolt is a thousand volts. Converting from kilovolts to volts: from large units to smaller units, requires more digits, decimal point moves to the right by three positions, a thousand times more.

Questions.Question: A current of one quarter ampere may be written as:
Questions.Explanation: One quarter ampere is 0.25 amperes. Milli is one thousandth. One ampere is a thousand milliamperes. Converting from ampere to milliampere: from large units to smaller units, requires more digits, decimal point moves to the right by three positions, a thousand times more.

Questions.Question: How many millivolts are equivalent to two volts?
Questions.Explanation: A millivolt is a thousandth of a volt. A volt is one thousand millivolts. Converting from volts to millivolts: from large units to smaller units, requires more digits, decimal point moves to the right by three positions, a thousand times more.

Questions.Question: Name three good electrical conductors.
Questions.Explanation: Wood, paper and mica do NOT conduct electricity. The best conductors, in descending order, are: Silver, Copper, Gold and Aluminum.

Questions.Question: Name four good electrical insulators.
Questions.Explanation: Copper and aluminum are CONDUCTORS. Carbon is a poor conductor, it is used to fabricate resistors.

Questions.Question: Why do resistors sometimes get hot when in use?
Answers: Some electrical energy passing through them is lost as heat
Their reactance makes them heat up
Hotter circuit components nearby heat them up
They absorb magnetic energy which makes them hot
Questions.Explanation: Power is voltage times current, P = E * I. When current flows through a resistor, a 'voltage drop' ensues. Volts times amperes become watts. Power is dissipated as heat.

Questions.Question: What is the best conductor among the following materials?
Questions.Explanation: The best conductors, in descending order, are: Silver, Copper, Gold and Aluminum. Carbon is a poor conductor, it is used to fabricate resistors. Silicon is used to make 'semiconductors'.

Questions.Question: Which type of material listed will most readily allow an electric current to flow?
Questions.Explanation: As the name implies, a 'conductor' readily passes electrical current. An Insulator ( synonym = dielectric ) does not let current flow. A resistor conducts but badly.

Questions.Question: A length of metal is connected in a circuit and is found to conduct electricity very well. It would be best described as having a:
Questions.Explanation: Conductors have LOW resistance. They do not oppose current flow.

Questions.Question: The letter "R" is the symbol for:
Questions.Explanation: R = Resistance, Z = Impedance, X = Reactance.

Questions.Question: The reciprocal of resistance is:
Questions.Explanation: Reciprocal = 'the inverse of something'. 1 over resistance yields CONDUCTANCE. Low resistance implies high conductance. High resistance implies little conductance.

Questions.Question: Voltage drop means:
Answers: the voltage developed across the terminals of a component
any point in a radio circuit which has zero voltage
the difference in voltage at output terminals of a transformer
the voltage which is dissipated before useful work is accomplished
Questions.Explanation: As current flows through electronic components, some voltage is 'lost'. Remember voltage as 'pressure',  there is more 'pressure' before a resistor than after it: this represents a 'voltage drop'.

Questions.Question: The resistance of a conductor changes with:
Questions.Explanation: Temperature affects components and conductors.

Questions.Question: The most common material used to make a resistor is:
Questions.Explanation: Carbon is a poor conductor. Gold and Lead are conductors. Mica is an insulator.

Questions.Question: Which electrical circuit will have no current?
Questions.Explanation: 'Open' circuit = no current ( a loop from one side of the voltage source to the other side does NOT exist, the loop is open ). 'Closed' circuit = current ( a path exists from one side of the voltage source to the other side, current flows, the loop is closed ). 'Short circuit' = heavy current ( a very low resistance path exists between from one side of the voltage source to the other side, large current ensues ).

Questions.Question: Which electrical circuit draws too much current?
Questions.Explanation: 'Open' circuit = no current ( a loop from one side of the voltage source to the other side does NOT exist, the loop is open ). 'Closed' circuit = current ( a path exists from one side of the voltage source to the other side, current flows, the loop is closed ). 'Short circuit' = heavy current ( a very low resistance path exists between from one side of the voltage source to the other side, large current ensues ).

Questions.Question: What term means the number of times per second that an alternating current flows back and forth?
Questions.Explanation: Frequency is the number of cycles per second of an Alternating Current (AC). Frequency is expressed in hertz (Hz). One hertz is one cycle per second.

Questions.Question: Approximately what frequency range can most humans hear?
Questions.Explanation: Hz = hertz = cycles per second. Frequencies audible to humans range from 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. Speech frequencies important for intelligibility in communications range from 300 Hz to 3000 Hz.

Questions.Question: Why do we call signals in the range 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz audio frequencies?
Answers: Because the human ear cannot sense anything in this range
Because this range is too low for radio energy
Because the human ear can sense radio waves in this range
Because the human ear can sense sounds in this range
Questions.Explanation: Hz = hertz = cycles per second. Frequencies audible to humans range from 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. Speech frequencies important for intelligibility in communications range from 300 Hz to 3000 Hz.

Questions.Question: What does 60 hertz (Hz) mean?
Questions.Explanation: Hz = hertz = cycles per second. Frequency is the number of cycles per second of an Alternating Current (AC). Frequency is expressed in hertz (Hz). One hertz is one cycle per second.

Questions.Question: If the frequency of the waveform is 100 Hz, the time for one cycle is:
Questions.Explanation: 100 Hz = 100 hertz = 100 cycles per second. The duration of ONE cycle, the "period", is 1 / frequency. In this Radiople, 1 / 100 Hz yields 0.01 second.

Questions.Question: Current in an AC circuit goes through a complete cycle in 0.1 second. This means the AC has a frequency of:
Questions.Explanation: One cycle in 0.1 second, how many cycles in a second ?  The duration of ONE cycle, the "period", and frequency have an inverse relation: Frequency is 1 / period. In this Radiople, 1 / 0.1 second yields 10 hertz.

Questions.Question: A signal is composed of a fundamental frequency of 2 kHz and another of 4 kHz. This 4 kHz signal is referred to as:
Answers: a fundamental of the 2 kHz signal
the DC component of the main signal
a dielectric signal of the main signal
a harmonic of the 2 kHz signal
Questions.Explanation: 'Harmonics' are integer MULTIPLES (e.g., 2x, 3x, 4x, 5x,...) of a given frequency. The base frequency is referred to as the 'fundamental'.

Questions.Question: A force of repulsion exists between two _________ magnetic poles.
Questions.Explanation: 'Like' magnetic poles repulse each other. 'Unlike' magnetic poles attract one another.

Questions.Question: A permanent magnet would most likely be made from:
Questions.Explanation: Copper, aluminum and brass are impervious to magnetic fields.

Questions.Question: How is a voltmeter usually connected to a circuit under test?
Questions.Explanation: An instrument to measure voltage. The voltmeter is always connected in parallel to measure a difference of potential between two points, across a component, etc.

Questions.Question: How is an ammeter usually connected to a circuit under test?
Questions.Explanation: Ammeter comes from the words ampere + meter, it is used to measure current. Current flows THROUGH a circuit. The circuit must be 'broken' and the ammeter inserted in series with the circuit to measure current. Ammeters have very low resistance and, thus, have little effect once inserted in the circuit.

Questions.Question: What does a multimeter measure?
Questions.Explanation: Common multimeters can measure the three basic electrical units: voltage (E), current (I) and resistance (R).

Questions.Question: The correct instrument to measure plate current or collector current of a transmitter is:
Questions.Explanation: Ammeter comes from the words ampere + meter, it is used to measure current.

Questions.Question: Which of the following meters would you use to measure the power supply current drawn by a small hand-held transistorized receiver?
Questions.Explanation: Ammeter comes from the words ampere + meter, it is used to measure current.

Questions.Question: When measuring current drawn from a DC power supply, it is true to say that the meter will act in circuit as:
Questions.Explanation: This is a bit of a catch. A PERFECT conductor would exhibit ZERO resistance. An ammeter actually has a very low resistance. [ For Radiople, a 10 A ammeter can have a resistance of 0.005 ohms, a 1 A ammeter can have 0.05 ohms and a 500 mA ammeter can introduce 0.2 ohms of resistance in the circuit. ]

Questions.Question: When measuring the current drawn by a receiver from a power supply, the current meter should be placed:
Answers: in parallel with one of the receiver power leads
in series with one of the receiver power leads
in series with both receiver power leads
in parallel with both receiver power supply leads
Questions.Explanation: Ammeter comes from the words ampere + meter, it is used to measure current. Current flows THROUGH a circuit. The circuit must be 'broken' and the ammeter inserted in series with the circuit to measure current. Ammeters have very low resistance and, thus, have little effect once inserted in the circuit.

Questions.Question: Potential difference is measured by means of:
Questions.Explanation: The voltmeter is always connected in parallel to measure a difference of potential between two points, across a component, etc.

Questions.Question: The instrument used for measuring the flow of electrical current is the:
Questions.Explanation: Ammeter comes from the words ampere + meter, it is used to measure current. Current flow THROUGH a circuit. The circuit must be 'broken' and the ammeter inserted in series with the circuit to measure current. Ammeters have very low resistance and, thus, have little effect once inserted in the circuit.

Questions.Question: In measuring volts and amperes, the connections should be made with:
Answers: the voltmeter in parallel and ammeter in series
the voltmeter in series and ammeter in parallel
both voltmeter and ammeter in series
both voltmeter and ammeter in parallel
Questions.Explanation: The voltmeter is always connected in parallel to measure a difference of potential between two points, across a component, etc. Ammeter comes from the words Ampere + meter, it is used to measure current. Current flow THROUGH a circuit. The circuit must be 'broken' and the ammeter inserted in series with the circuit to measure current. Ammeters have very low resistance and, thus, have little effect once inserted in the circuit.

Questions.Question: If you have a hand-held transceiver which puts out 500 milliwatts, how many watts would this be?
Questions.Explanation: A thousand milliwatts is one watt. Converting from milliwatts to watts: from small units to larger units, requires fewer digits, decimal point moves to the left by three positions, a thousand times less.

Questions.Question: What is the word used to describe the rate at which electrical energy is used?
Questions.Explanation: The watt is the unit used to measure the rate of energy use.

Questions.Question: If you have light bulbs marked 40 watts, 60 watts and 100 watts, which one will use electrical energy the fastest?
Answers: They will all be the same
Questions.Explanation: How fast does each one make the electrical utility meter on the side of your house spin ?  The device with the highest wattage spins it the fastest.

Questions.Question: What is the basic unit of electrical power?
Questions.Explanation: Power, expressed in watts = voltage, in volts, TIMES current, in amperes. P = E * I. Watts = volts * amperes. The watt describe how fast electrical energy is used.

Questions.Question: Power is expressed in:
Questions.Explanation: Power, expressed in watts = voltage, in volts, TIMES current, in amperes. P = E * I. Watts = volts * amperes. The watt describe how fast electrical energy is used.

Questions.Question: Which of the following two quantities should be multiplied together to find power?
Questions.Explanation: Power, expressed in watts = voltage, in volts, TIMES current, in amperes. P = E * I. Watts = volts * amperes. The watt describe how fast electrical energy is used.

Questions.Question: Which two electrical units multiplied together give the unit "watts"?
Questions.Explanation: Power, expressed in watts = voltage, in volts, TIMES current, in amperes. P = E * I. Watts = volts * amperes. The watt describe how fast electrical energy is used.

Questions.Question: A resistor in a circuit becomes very hot and starts to burn. This is because the resistor is dissipating too much:
Questions.Explanation: Power is voltage times current, P = E * I. When current flows through a resistor, a 'voltage drop' ensues. Volts times amperes become watts. Power is dissipated as heat.

Questions.Question: High power resistors are usually large with heavy leads. The size aids the operation of the resistor by:
Answers: allowing heat to dissipate more readily
allowing higher voltage to be handled
increasing the effective resistance of the resistor
Questions.Explanation: Resistors are rated for resistance in ohms and safe power dissipation in watts.

Questions.Question: The resistor that could dissipate the most heat would be marked:
Questions.Explanation: Resistors are rated for resistance in ohms and safe power dissipation in watts.

Questions.Question: If a current of 2 amperes flows through a 50-ohm resistor, what is the voltage across the resistor?
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ) becomes E = R*I when solving for E. Voltage = resistance times current. Volts = ohms * amperes. 50 ohms * 2 amperes = 100 volts.

Questions.Question: How is the current in a DC circuit calculated when the voltage and resistance are known?
Answers: Current equals resistance multiplied by voltage
Current equals resistance divided by voltage
Current equals power divided by voltage
Current equals voltage divided by resistance
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law is I = E / R, current is voltage divided by resistance. Amperes = volts / ohms.

Questions.Question: How is the resistance in a DC circuit calculated when the voltage and current are known?
Answers: Resistance equals current divided by voltage
Resistance equals voltage divided by current
Resistance equals current multiplied by voltage
Resistance equals power divided by voltage
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ) becomes R = E / I when solving for R. Resistance is voltage divided by current. Ohms = volts / amperes.

Questions.Question: How is the voltage in a DC circuit calculated when the current and resistance are known?
Answers: Voltage equals current multiplied by resistance
Voltage equals current divided by resistance
Voltage equals resistance divided by current
Voltage equals power divided by current
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ) becomes E = R*I when solving for E. Voltage is resistance times current. Volts = ohms * amperes.

Questions.Question: If a 12-volt battery supplies 0.25 ampere to a circuit, what is the circuit's resistance?
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ) becomes R = E / I when solving for R. Resistance is voltage divided by current. Ohms = volts / amperes. 12 volts / 0.25 amperes = 48 ohms.

Questions.Question: Calculate the value of resistance necessary to drop 100 volts with current flow of 0.8 milliamperes:
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ) becomes R = E / I when solving for R. Resistance is voltage divided by current. Ohms = volts / amperes. 100 volts / 0.0008 amperes = 125,000 ohms = 125 kilohms. [ Note that volts divided by milliamperes is kilohm ]

Questions.Question: The voltage required to force a current of 4.4 amperes through a resistance of 50 ohms is:
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ) becomes E = R*I when solving for E. Voltage is resistance times current. Volts = ohms * amperes. 50 ohms * 4.4 amperes = 220 volts.

Questions.Question: A lamp has a resistance of 30 ohms and a 6 volt battery is connected. The current flow will be:
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ). Current is voltage divided by resistance. Amperes = volts / ohms. 6 volts / 30 ohms = 0.2 amperes.

Questions.Question: What voltage would be needed to supply a current of 200 milliamperes, to operate an electric lamp which has a resistance of 25 ohms?
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ) becomes E = R*I when solving for E. Voltage is resistance times current. Volts = ohms * amperes. 25 ohms * 0.200 amperes = 5 volts.

Questions.Question: The resistance of a circuit can be found by using one of the following:
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ) becomes R = E / I when solving for R. Resistance is voltage divided by current. Ohms = volts / amperes.

Questions.Question: If a 3 volt battery supplies 300 milliamperes to a circuit, the circuit resistance is:
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ) becomes R = E / I when solving for R. Resistance is voltage divided by current. Ohms = volts / amperes. 3 volts / 0.300 amperes = 10 ohms.

Questions.Question: In a parallel circuit with a voltage source and several branch resistors, how is the total current related to the current in the branch resistors?
Answers: It equals the average of the branch current through each resistor
It decreases as more parallel resistors are added to the circuit
It is the sum of each resistor's voltage drop multiplied by the total number of resistors
It equals the sum of the branch current through each resistor
Questions.Explanation: Each resistor added in parallel to the source draws some current ( in accordance with Ohm's Law, I = E / R ). The total current that the source must supply becomes the SUM of all these individual currents. Just like in your house, the total current drawn from the utility company is the sum of all the devices turned-on.

Questions.Question: Three resistors, respectively rated at 10, 15 and 20 ohms are connected in parallel across a 6-volt battery. Which statement is true?
Answers: The voltage drop across each resistance added together equals 6 volts
The voltage drop across the 20 ohm resistance is greater than the voltage across the 10 ohm resistance
The current through the 10 ohms, 15 ohms and 20 ohms separate resistances, when added together, equals the total current drawn from the battery
The current flowing through the 10 ohm resistance is less than that flowing through the 20 ohm resistance
Questions.Explanation: In a parallel circuit, the total current is the sum of the currents. All resistors are subjected to the same voltage in a PARALLEL circuit. Ohm's Law tells us that the smaller resistor will draw more current than the others.

Questions.Question: Total resistance in a parallel circuit:
Answers: depends upon the voltage drop across each branch
could be equal to the resistance of one branch
is always less than the smallest resistance
Questions.Explanation: In a parallel circuit, each added resistor adds to the current drawn from the source. If more and more current is drawn, the total resistance must be going down. In PARALLEL, the total resistance is less than the smallest.

Questions.Question: Two resistors are connected in parallel and are connected across a 40 volt battery. If each resistor is 1000 ohms, the total current is:
Questions.Explanation: Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ). Each resistor draws this much current: 40 volts divided by 1000 ohms = 0.040 amperes = 40 milliamperes. In PARALLEL, total current is the sum of the currents. Method B: identical resistors in parallel, total resistance is value divided by number. In this case, 1000 / 2 = 500 ohms. 40 volts / 500 ohms = 0.08 amperes = 80 milliamperes.

Questions.Question: The total resistance of resistors connected in series is:
Answers: equal to the lowest resistance present
greater than the resistance of any one resistor
less than the resistance of any one resistor
equal to the highest resistance present
Questions.Explanation: In a series circuit, there is only one current. This current must wrestle with each resistor one after the other. In SERIES, total resistance is the sum of the resistances. The same current flows through all of them.

Questions.Question: Five 10 ohm resistors connected in series equals:
Questions.Explanation: In SERIES, total resistance is the sum of the resistances.

Questions.Question: Which series combination of resistors would replace a single 120 ohm resistor?
Questions.Explanation: In SERIES, total resistance is the sum of the resistances. Five times twenty-four = 120.

Questions.Question: If ten resistors of equal value were wired in parallel, the total resistance would be:
Questions.Explanation: In a parallel circuit with IDENTICAL resistors, total resistance is value divided by number. In this Radiople, the value of one R divided by 10.

Questions.Question: The total resistance of four 68 ohm resistors wired in parallel is:
Questions.Explanation: In a parallel circuit with IDENTICAL resistors, total resistance is value divided by number. In this Radiople, 68 / 4 yields 17.

Questions.Question: Two resistors are in parallel. Resistor A carries twice the current of resistor B, which means that:
Answers: the voltage across A is twice that across B
B has half the resistance of A
A has half the resistance of B
the voltage across B is twice that across A
Questions.Explanation: All resistors in a parallel circuit are subjected to the same voltage. Per Ohm's Law ( I = E / R, current = voltage divided by resistance ), if resistor A draws twice the current of resistor B, it must have half the resistance of Resistor B.

Questions.Question: The total current in a parallel circuit is equal to the:
Answers: source voltage divided by the sum of the resistive elements
current in any one of the parallel branches
sum of the currents through all the parallel branches
source voltage divided by the value of one of the resistive elements
Questions.Explanation: In a parallel circuit, the total current is the sum of the currents. Each branch is subjected to the same voltage and draws a current in accordance with Ohm's Law ( I = E / R, current = voltage divided by resistance ).

Questions.Question: Why would a large size resistor be used instead of a smaller one of the same resistance?
Answers: For less impedance in the circuit
Questions.Explanation: Remember that power is voltage times current, P = E * I. A resistor dissipates power into heat. A resistor can only dissipate so much power without burning up: i.e., its power rating. Larger resistors can dissipate more heat.

Questions.Question: How many watts of electrical power are used by a 12 volt DC light bulb that draws 0.2 ampere?
Questions.Explanation: P = E * I, power is voltage times current, watts = volts * amperes. 12 volts * 0.2 amperes = 2.4 watts  [ VDC = volts in a Direct Current circuit ]

Questions.Question: The DC input power of a transmitter operating at 12 volts and drawing 500 milliamperes would be:
Questions.Explanation: P = E * I, power is voltage times current, watts = volts * amperes. 12 volts * 0.5 amperes = 6 watts.

Questions.Question: When two 500 ohm 1 watt resistors are connected in series, the maximum total power that can be dissipated by the resistors is:
Questions.Explanation: This is about POWER RATING, not resistance. Two identical resistors can safely dissipate TWICE as much power as only one. [ Yes, total resistance will be twice as much, but that is immaterial here ]

Questions.Question: When two 500 ohm 1 watt resistors are connected in parallel, they can dissipate a maximum total power of:
Questions.Explanation: This is about POWER RATING, not resistance. Two identical resistors can safely dissipate TWICE as much power as only one. [ Yes, total resistance will be half, but that is immaterial here ]

Questions.Question: If the voltage applied to two resistors in series is doubled, how much will the total power change?
Questions.Explanation: P = E * I, power is voltage times current, watts = volts * amperes. Given the proportional relation of current versus voltage stated by Ohm's Law, if you double voltage in a circuit, current will double. Power is voltage times current, if both double, power has quadrupled ( 4 times more ).

Questions.Question: Which combination of resistors could make up a 50 ohms dummy load capable of safely dissipating 5 watts?
Answers: Ten quarter-watt 500 ohms resistors in parallel
Questions.Explanation: Four 200 ohms @ 2 watts in parallel = 50 ohms @ 8 watts. Two 25 ohms @ 2 watts in series = 50 ohms @ 4 watts. Ten 500 ohms @ 0.25 watts in parallel = 50 ohms @ 2.5 watts. Two 100 ohms @ 5 watts in series = 200 ohms @ 10 watts.

Questions.Question: A 12 volt light bulb is rated at a power of 30 watts. The current drawn would be:
Questions.Explanation: The Power Law: P = E * I, power is voltage times current. Transformed to solve for I, it becomes I = P / E. In this Radiople, I = 30 watts / 12 volts.

Questions.Question: If two 10 ohm resistors are connected in series with a 10 volt battery, the power consumption would be:
Questions.Explanation: Two 10 ohm resistors in series present a total resistance of 20 ohms. Use Ohm's Law ( I = E / R ) to compute current as 10 volts divided by 20 ohms = 0.5 amperes. The Power Law: P = E * I, power is voltage times current. Power for this Radiople becomes 10 volts times 0.5 amperes = 5 watts.

Questions.Question: One advantage of replacing a 50 ohm resistor with a parallel combination of two similarly rated 100 ohm resistors is that the parallel combination will have:
Answers: lesser resistance and similar power rating
the same resistance but greater power rating
the same resistance but lesser power rating
greater resistance and similar power rating
Questions.Explanation: This is about POWER RATING, not resistance. Two identical resistors can safely dissipate TWICE as much power as only one. Two resistors of 100 ohms in PARALLEL yield a total resistance of 50 ohms ( In a parallel circuit with IDENTICAL resistors, total resistance is value divided by number ).

Questions.Question: Resistor wattage ratings are:
Answers: variable in steps of one hundred
calculated according to physical size and tolerance rating
Questions.Explanation: Materials, shape, construction all interact to determine heat dissipation capabilities. Tolerance is a misleading clue.

Questions.Question: If a dial marked in megahertz shows a reading of 3.525 MHz, what would it show if it were marked in kilohertz?
Questions.Explanation: Mega is a million, kilo is a thousand. A megahertz is a thousand kilohertz. Converting from megahertz to kilohertz, from large units to smaller, requires more digits, decimal point moves to the right by three positions, a thousand times more.

Questions.Question: One megahertz is equal to:
Questions.Explanation: Mega is a million, kilo is a thousand. Converting from megahertz to kilohertz, from large units to smaller, requires more digits, decimal point moves to the right by three positions, a thousand times more.

Questions.Question: Electrical energy at a frequency of 7125 kHz is in what frequency range?
Questions.Explanation: Frequencies audible to humans range from 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz (AUDIO). Speech frequencies important for intelligibility in communications range from 300 Hz to 3000 Hz. Radio frequencies can reach up to 300 GHz ( 300,000 MHz ): Medium Frequencies 300 kHz - 3000 kHz, High Frequencies 3 MHz - 30 MHz, Very High Frequencies 30 MHz - 300 MHz, Ultra High Frequencies 300 MHz - 3000 MHz, Super High Frequencies 3 GHz - 30 GHz, Extremely High Frequencies 30 GHz - 300 GHz.

Questions.Question: What is the name for the distance an AC signal travels during one complete cycle?
Questions.Explanation: Wavelength: the distance between successive points of equal amplitude and phase on a wave (for Radiople, crest to crest or trough to trough).

Questions.Question: What happens to a signal's wavelength as its frequency increases?
Questions.Explanation: Wavelength (lambda) in metres is 300 divided by frequency in megahertz ( i.e., the speed of light divided by the frequency in hertz ). Wavelength and frequency have an inverse relationship.

Questions.Question: What happens to a signal's frequency as its wavelength gets longer?
Questions.Explanation: Wavelength (lambda) in metres is 300 divided by frequency in megahertz ( i.e., the speed of light divided by the frequency in hertz ).  Wavelength and frequency have an inverse relationship.

Questions.Question: How many microfarads is 1,000,000 picofarads?
Questions.Explanation: Pico is a millionth of a millionth, micro is a millionth. Converting from picofarads to microfarads: from small units to larger units, requires fewer digits, decimal point moves to the left by SIX positions, a MILLION times less.

Questions.Question: An inductance of 10,000 microhenrys may be stated correctly as:
Questions.Explanation: Micro is a millionth, milli is a thousandth. Converting from microhenrys to millihenrys: from small units to larger units, requires fewer digits, decimal point moves to the left by three positions, a thousand times less.

Questions.Question: If two equal-value inductors are connected in series, what is their total inductance?
Answers: Half the value of one inductor
The same as the value of either inductor
The value of one inductor times the value of the other
Twice the value of one inductor
Questions.Explanation: Inductors (coils) in combinations obey rules similar to resistors. In SERIES, the total value is the sum of the values. In PARALLEL combination with components of IDENTICAL values, the total value is the value of one component divided by the number in the circuit.

Questions.Question: If two equal-value inductors are connected in parallel, what is their total inductance?
Answers: The value of one inductor times the value of the other
Half the value of one inductor
Twice the value of one inductor
The same as the value of either inductor
Questions.Explanation: Inductors (coils) in combinations obey rules similar to resistors. In PARALLEL combination with components of IDENTICAL values, the total value is the value of one component divided by the number in the circuit. In SERIES, the total value is the sum of the values.

Questions.Question: If two equal-value capacitors are connected in series, what is their total capacitance?
Answers: Twice the value of one capacitor
The same as the value of either capacitor
The value of one capacitor times the value of the other
Half the value of either capacitor
Questions.Explanation: Capacitors behave OPPOSITE TO INDUCTORS. Capacitors add up in parallel combinations BUT the total value is less than the smallest in a series combination. With identical CAPACITORS in SERIES, the total value is the value of one component divided by the number in the circuit.

Questions.Question: If two equal-value capacitors are connected in parallel, what is their total capacitance?
Answers: The value of one capacitor times the value of the other
Half the value of one capacitor
Twice the value of one capacitor
The same as the value of either capacitor
Questions.Explanation: Capacitors behave OPPOSITE TO INDUCTORS. With CAPACITORS in PARALLEL, the total value is the sum of the values. Picture in your head, the area of the plates growing as more and more capacitors are added in parallel. More plate area, more capacity.

Questions.Question: What determines the inductance of a coil?
Answers: The coil diameter, the number of turns of wire used to wind the coil and the type of metal used for the wire
The core material, the coil diameter, the length of the coil and whether the coil is mounted horizontally or vertically
The core material, the coil diameter, the length of the coil and the number of turns of wire used to wind the coil
The core material, the number of turns used to wind the coil and the frequency of the current through the coil
Questions.Explanation: Inductance in a coil is due to the interaction of the magnetic fields from one turn to the others. The ease of setting up a magnetic field through a suitable core material, the relative position of the turns (diameter and length) and the number of turns all contribute to inductance.

Questions.Question: What determines the capacitance of a capacitor?
Answers: The material between the plates, the area of one plate, the number of plates and the material used for the protective coating
The material between the plates, the surface area of the plates, the number of plates and the spacing between the plates
The material between the plates, the number of plates and the size of the wires connected to the plates
The number of plates, the spacing between the plates and whether the dielectric material is N type or P type
Questions.Explanation: A simple capacitor is two plates next to one another. The material used as a dielectric to insulate the two plates and the distance between the plates influence the importance of the electric field that can be set-up. The area and number of plates multiply the capacitance effect.

Questions.Question: If two equal-value capacitors are connected in parallel, what is their capacitance?
Answers: The value of one capacitor times the value of the other
Half the value of either capacitor
Twice the value of either capacitor
The same value of either capacitor
Questions.Explanation: Capacitors behave OPPOSITE TO INDUCTORS. With CAPACITORS in PARALLEL, the total value is the sum of the values. Picture in your head, the area of the plates growing as more and more capacitors are added in parallel. More plate area, more capacity.

Questions.Question: To replace a faulty 10 millihenry choke, you could use two:
Questions.Explanation: Inductors (coils) in combinations obey rules similar to resistors. In SERIES, the total value is the sum of the values.

Questions.Question: Three 15 microfarad capacitors are wired in series. The total capacitance of this arrangement is:
Questions.Explanation: Capacitors behave OPPOSITE TO INDUCTORS. Capacitors add up in parallel combinations BUT the total value is less than the smallest in a series combination. With identical CAPACITORS in SERIES, the total value is the value of one component divided by the number in the circuit.

Questions.Question: Which series combinations of capacitors would best replace a faulty 10 microfarad capacitor?
Questions.Explanation: Capacitors behave OPPOSITE TO INDUCTORS. Capacitors add up in parallel combinations BUT the total value is less than the smallest in a series combination. With identical CAPACITORS in SERIES, the total value is the value of one component divided by the number in the circuit. [ capacitors in series might be useful to augment the overall voltage rating ]

Questions.Question: The total capacitance of two or more capacitors in series is:
Answers: always greater than the largest capacitor
always less than the smallest capacitor
found by adding each of the capacitors together and dividing by the total number of capacitors
found by adding each of the capacitors together
Questions.Explanation: Capacitors behave OPPOSITE TO INDUCTORS. Capacitors add up in parallel combinations BUT the total value is less than the smallest in a series combination. With identical CAPACITORS in SERIES, the total value is the value of one component divided by the number in the circuit.

Questions.Question: How does a coil react to AC?
Answers: As the frequency of the applied AC increases, the reactance decreases
As the frequency of the applied AC increases, the reactance increases
As the amplitude of the applied AC increases, the reactance decreases
As the amplitude of the applied AC increases, the reactance increases
Questions.Explanation: Reactance is opposition. XL = 2 * PI * f * L. Inductive reactance = two times PI (i.e., 3.14) times frequency in hertz times inductance in henrys. Reactance (opposition) is not influenced by the amplitude of the applied voltage. If frequency goes up, inductive reactance goes up. Intuitively, the higher the frequency (i.e., rate of change), the more significant become the counter-currents induced in adjacent turns.

Questions.Question: How does a capacitor react to AC?
Answers: As the frequency of the applied AC increases, the reactance increases
As the amplitude of the applied AC increases, the reactance increases
As the amplitude of the applied AC increases, the reactance decreases
As the frequency of the applied AC increases, the reactance decreases
Questions.Explanation: Reactance is opposition. XC = 1 over ( 2 * PI * f * C ). Capacitive Reactance = 1 over the product of 'two times PI (i.e., 3.14) times frequency in hertz times capacitance in farads'. A behaviour opposite to inductors. Reactance (opposition) is not influenced by the amplitude of the applied voltage. If frequency goes up, capacitive reactance goes down. Intuitively, the more frequent the change of polarity (AC changes polarity every half-cycle), the more incessant becomes the charge/discharge current, current never seems to stop, less apparent opposition to current flow.

Questions.Question: The reactance of capacitors increases as:
Questions.Explanation: Reactance is opposition. XC = 1 over ( 2 * PI * f * C ). Capacitive Reactance = 1 over the product of 'two times PI (i.e., 3.14) times frequency in hertz times capacitance in farads'. A behaviour opposite to inductors. Reactance (opposition) is not influenced by the amplitude of the applied voltage. If frequency goes up, capacitive reactance goes down. Intuitively, the more frequent the change of polarity (AC changes polarity every half-cycle), the more incessant becomes the charge/discharge current, current never seems to stop, less apparent opposition to current flow.

Questions.Question: In inductances, AC may be opposed by both resistance of winding wire and reactance due to inductive effect. The term which includes resistance and reactance is:
Questions.Explanation: Impedance is measured in ohms. It is the combined effect of reactance(s) and resistance. Resistance affects DC and AC equally. Reactance is a property only present under AC. [ DC = direct current, AC = alternating current ]

Questions.Question: Capacitive reactance:
Answers: applies only to series RLC circuits
Questions.Explanation: Reactance is opposition. XC = 1 over ( 2 * PI * f * C ). Capacitive Reactance = 1 over the product of 'two times PI (i.e., 3.14) times frequency in hertz times capacitance in farads'. A behaviour opposite to inductors. Reactance (opposition) is not influenced by the amplitude of the applied voltage. If frequency goes up, capacitive reactance goes down. Intuitively, the more frequent the change of polarity (AC changes polarity every half-cycle), the more incessant becomes the charge/discharge current, current never seems to stop, less apparent opposition to current flow.

Questions.Question: Inductive reactance may be increased by:
Answers: an increase in the applied voltage
an increase in the applied frequency
a decrease in the applied frequency
a decrease in the supplied current
Questions.Explanation: Reactance is opposition. XL = 2 * PI * f * L. Inductive reactance = two times PI (i.e., 3.14) times frequency in hertz times inductance in henrys. Reactance (opposition) is not influenced by the amplitude of the applied voltage. If frequency goes up, inductive reactance goes up. Intuitively, the higher the frequency (i.e., rate of change), the more significant become the counter-currents induced in adjacent turns.

Questions.Question: What property allows a coil wound on a ferrite core to mitigate the effects of an offending radio signal?
Questions.Explanation: The coil (inductor) when dealing with an offending radio signal: chokes-off radio frequency (high reactance), but passes audio frequencies (low reactance). Recall that the opposition of a coil to AC current flow (inductive reactance) grows as frequency increases.

Questions.Question: What property allows an RF bypass capacitor on an audio circuit to divert an offending radio signal?
Questions.Explanation: The bypass capacitor must provide a low impedance path for an offending signal without affecting lower frequency signals: low reactance for radio frequency, high reactance for audio. Recall that the opposition of a capacitor to AC current flow (capacitive reactance) decreases as frequency goes up.

Questions.Question: What property allows an RF bypass capacitor to have little effect on an audio circuit?
Questions.Explanation: The bypass capacitor must provide a low impedance path for an offending signal without affecting lower frequency signals: low reactance for radio frequency, high reactance for audio. Recall that the opposition of a capacitor to AC current flow (capacitive reactance) decreases as frequency goes up.

Questions.Question: What property allows an RF choke coil to have little effect on signals meant to flow through the coil?
Questions.Explanation: The coil (inductor) when dealing with an offending radio signal: chokes-off radio frequency (high reactance), but passes audio frequencies (low reactance). Recall that the opposition of a coil to AC current flow (inductive reactance) grows as frequency increases.

Questions.Question: In general, the reactance of inductors increases with:
Questions.Explanation: Reactance is opposition. XL = 2 * PI * f * L. Inductive reactance = two times PI (i.e., 3.14) times frequency in hertz times inductance in henrys. Reactance (opposition) is not influenced by the amplitude of the applied voltage. If frequency goes up, inductive reactance goes up. Intuitively, the higher the frequency (i.e., rate of change), the more significant become the counter-currents induced in adjacent turns.

Questions.Question: If no load is attached to the secondary winding of a transformer, what is current in the primary winding called?
Questions.Explanation: Even if no current is drawn from the secondary of the transformer, the primary winding remains an inductor. It lets some AC current through despite its reactance. This minimal current is called "Magnetizing current".

Questions.Question: A transformer operates a 6.3 volt 2 ampere light bulb from its secondary winding. The input power to the primary winding is approximately:
Questions.Explanation: The Power Law: P = E * I, power is voltage times current. 6.3 volts * 2 amperes = 12.6 watts

Questions.Question: A transformer has a 240 volt primary that draws a current of 250 milliamperes from the mains supply. Assuming no losses and only one secondary, what current would be available from the 12 volt secondary?
Questions.Explanation: As work is performed at a lower voltage on the secondary side, current on the secondary is larger. The turns ratio is '20 to 1' ( 240 volts to 12 volts ), the current ratio follows the inverse of that ratio: 20 * 0.25 amperes = 5 amperes. Method B: Primary consumes 60 watts  ( 240 volts * 0.25 amperes ),  secondary must draw that same power (discounting losses). What is the secondary current for 60 watts at 12 volts ?  I = P / E (derived from P = E * I), I = 60 watts / 12 volts = 5 amperes.

Questions.Question: In a mains power transformer, the primary winding has 250 turns, and the secondary has 500. If the input voltage is 120 volts, the likely secondary voltage is:
Questions.Explanation: A 'step-up' transformer, the secondary uses twice as many turns as the primary, voltage is doubled ( exactly per the turns ratio ).

Questions.Question: The strength of the magnetic field around a conductor in air is:
Answers: inversely proportional to the voltage on the conductor
directly proportional to the current in the conductor
inversely proportional to the diameter of the conductor
directly proportional to the diameter of the conductor
Questions.Explanation: Current and magnetism are closely related: current in a conductor sets up a magnetic field, dropping a conductor through magnetic lines of force creates a current. Voltage which would only be of concern for an electrical field. Reference to the conductor's diameter is a useless clue.

Questions.Question: Maximum induced voltage in a coil occurs when:
Answers: current is going through its greatest rate of change
the current through the coil is of a DC nature
current is going through its least rate of change
the magnetic field around the coil is not changing
Questions.Explanation: For induction to take place in a wire, a conductor must be subjected to a moving magnetic field (no movement, no induction). Either the conductor must move in the magnetic field  OR  the magnetic field must move if the conductor is immobile. If current changes drastically within a short period of time ('rate of change'), the magnetic field around the conductor changes rapidly, induction is maximized.

Questions.Question: The voltage induced in a conductor moving in a magnetic field is at a maximum when the movement is:
Answers: perpendicular to the lines of force
made in a counter clockwise direction
parallel to the lines of force
Questions.Explanation: For induction to be maximum, the conductor must "cut" through the lines of magnetic force. Dropping through perpendicularly (at 90 degrees) through the magnetic field maximizes induction.

Questions.Question: A 100% efficient transformer has a turns ratio of 1/5. If the secondary current is 50 milliamperes, the primary current is:
Questions.Explanation: A turns ratio of '1 to 5' indicates a 'step-up' transformer, primary current will be larger than the secondary current by the inverse of that ratio. In this Radiople, primary current is 5 * times 50 mA = 250 milliamperes = 0.25 amperes. Transformers do not "create" power out of nothing, the power ( E * I ) flowing into the primary equals the power drawn by the secondary plus losses (which are ignored for the sake of simplicity). For power to remain "comparable" on both sides of the transformer, current goes up if voltage increases  and  vice-versa.

Questions.Question: The fact that energy transfer from primary to secondary windings in a power transformer is not perfect is indicated by:
Questions.Explanation: Heating of the core laminations is a symptom of one of the losses in a real-life transformer.

Questions.Question: Resonance is the condition that exists when:
Answers: inductive reactance is the only opposition in the circuit
resistance is equal to the reactance
inductive reactance and capacitive reactance are equal
Questions.Explanation: Resonance is the condition where Inductive Reactance (XL) is equal in value to Capacitive Reactance (XC). For a given Inductance (L, a coil or inductor) and Capacitance (C, a capacitor), resonance happens at one frequency: the resonant frequency. At resonance, the two reactances cancel each other, only resistance is left in the circuit.

Questions.Question: Parallel tuned circuits offer:
Answers: an impedance equal to resistance of the circuit
Questions.Explanation: Question refers to Resonance. The one frequency at which Inductive Reactance cancels Capacitive Reactance. In a PARALLEL circuit, Impedance (Z) at resonance is HIGH ( series circuit will be the opposite ). As a memory aid, try to visualize the PARALLEL circuit as a tub or tank, signals get trapped at resonance. Try to visualize the SERIES circuit as a slim tube, signals slip right through at resonance.

Questions.Question: Resonance is an electrical property used to describe:
Answers: the results of tuning a varicap (varactor)
the frequency characteristic of a coil and capacitor circuit
Questions.Explanation: Resonance is the condition where Inductive Reactance (XL) is equal in value to Capacitive Reactance (XC). For a given Inductance (L, a coil or inductor) and Capacitance (C, a capacitor), resonance happens at one frequency: the resonant frequency. At resonance, the two reactances cancel each other, only resistance is left in the circuit.

Questions.Question: A tuned circuit is formed from two basic components. These are:
Questions.Explanation: A 'tuned' circuit is a synonym for a 'resonant' circuit. Resonance is the condition where Inductive Reactance (XL) is equal in value to Capacitive Reactance (XC). Inductors and Capacitors alone determine the resonant frequency of a circuit.

Questions.Question: When a parallel coil-capacitor combination is supplied with AC of different frequencies, there will be one frequency where the impedance will be highest. This is the:
Questions.Explanation: A 'tuned' circuit. Question refers to Resonance. The one frequency at which Inductive Reactance cancels Capacitive Reactance. In a PARALLEL circuit, Impedance (Z) at resonance is HIGH ( series circuit will be the opposite ). As a memory aid, try to visualize the PARALLEL circuit as a tub or tank, signals get trapped at resonance. Try to visualize the SERIES circuit as a slim tube, signals slip right through at resonance.

Questions.Question: In a parallel-resonant circuit at resonance, the circuit has a:
Questions.Explanation: Question refers to Resonance. The one frequency at which Inductive Reactance cancels Capacitive Reactance. In a PARALLEL circuit, Impedance (Z) at resonance is HIGH ( series circuit will be the opposite ). As a memory aid, try to visualize the PARALLEL circuit as a tub or tank, signals get trapped at resonance. Try to visualize the SERIES circuit as a slim tube, signals slip right through at resonance.

Questions.Question: In a series resonant circuit at resonance, the circuit has:
Questions.Explanation: Question refers to Resonance. The one frequency at which Inductive Reactance cancels Capacitive Reactance. In a SERIES circuit, Impedance (Z) at resonance is LOW ( parallel circuit will be the opposite ). If Impedance is low (little total opposition), current will be high. As a memory aid, try to visualize the SERIES circuit as a slim tube, signals slip right through at resonance. Try to visualize the PARALLEL circuit as a tub or tank, signals get trapped at resonance.

Questions.Question: A coil and an air-spaced capacitor are arranged to form a resonant circuit. The resonant frequency will remain the same if we:
Answers: wind more turns on the coil
add a resistor to the circuit
increase the area of plates in the capacitor
insert Mylar sheets between the plates of the capacitor
Questions.Explanation: Resonance is affected exclusively by Inductance (L in henrys for inductors) and Capacitance ( C in farads for capacitors ). Capacitance is affected by the area of the plates and the choice of dielectric. Inductance is affected by the number of turns in a coil.

Questions.Question: Resonant circuits in a receiver are used to:
Questions.Explanation: Resonance is about choosing a frequency (or narrow range of frequencies) over others, either to eliminate it or favour it.

Questions.Question: Resonance is the condition that exists when:
Answers: resistance is equal to the reactance
inductive reactance and capacitive reactance are equal and opposite in sign
inductive reactance is the only opposition in the circuit
Questions.Explanation: Resonance is the condition where Inductive Reactance (XL) is equal in value to Capacitive Reactance (XC). For a given Inductance (L, a coil or inductor) and Capacitance (C, a capacitor), resonance happens at one frequency: the resonant frequency. At resonance, the two reactances cancel each other, only resistance is left in the circuit.

Questions.Question: When a series LCR circuit is tuned to the frequency of the source, the:
Answers: line current leads the applied voltage
line current lags the applied voltage
Questions.Explanation: Question refers to Resonance. The one frequency at which Inductive Reactance cancels Capacitive Reactance. In a SERIES circuit, Impedance (Z) at resonance is LOW ( parallel circuit will be the opposite ). If Impedance is low (little total opposition), current will be high. As a memory aid, try to visualize the SERIES circuit as a slim tube, signals slip right through at resonance. Try to visualize the PARALLEL circuit as a tub or tank, signals get trapped at resonance.
