Questions.Question: When will a power source deliver maximum output to the load?
Answers: When the load resistance is infinite
When the impedance of the load is equal to the impedance of the source
When air wound transformers are used instead of iron-core transformers
When the power-supply fuse rating equals the primary winding current
Questions.Explanation: Impedance Match: maximum power transfer occurs when the impedance of the load matches the internal impedance of the source. For Radiople, a transmitter designed to work into an impedance of 50 ohms, will delivered maximum power if the antenna system offers an impedance of 50 ohms.

Questions.Question: What happens when the impedance of an electrical load is equal to the internal impedance of the power source?
Answers: The source delivers minimum power to the load
The source delivers maximum power to the load
No current can flow through the circuit
Questions.Explanation: Impedance Match: maximum power transfer occurs when the impedance of the load matches the internal impedance of the source. For Radiople, a transmitter designed to work into an impedance of 50 ohms, will delivered maximum power if the antenna system offers an impedance of 50 ohms.

Questions.Question: Why is impedance matching important?
Answers: So the source can deliver maximum power to the load
So the load will draw minimum power from the source
To ensure that there is less resistance than reactance in the circuit
To ensure that the resistance and reactance in the circuit are equal
Questions.Explanation: Impedance Match: maximum power transfer occurs when the impedance of the load matches the internal impedance of the source. For Radiople, a transmitter designed to work into an impedance of 50 ohms, will delivered maximum power if the antenna system offers an impedance of 50 ohms.

Title: Regulations, Part II: Standards, Restrictions, Identification.

Questions.Question: An amateur radio station with a maximum input power to the final stage of 2 watts:
Answers: is exempt from regulatory control by Industry Canada
must be operated by a person with an Amateur Certificate and call sign
must be licensed by Industry Canada
need not be licensed in isolated areas only
Questions.Explanation: Reference to power is misleading. ALL Amateur stations must be duly authorized.

Questions.Question: An amateur station may be used to communicate with:
Answers: any station transmitting in the amateur bands
any stations which are identified for special contests
armed forces stations during special contests and training exercises
Questions.Explanation: This is a catch. "any station transmitting in the amateur bands" seems reasonable until you think that this other station may be operating unlawfully without a certificate. "Stations operated under similar authorizations" is a much better answer. Amateurs are not allowed to knowingly conduct conversations with unauthorized stations ("bootleggers").

Questions.Question: Which of the following statements is not correct?
Answers: A radio amateur may not operate, or permit to be operated, a radio apparatus which he knows is not performing to the Radiocommunication Regulations
A radio amateur may use a linear amplifier to amplify the output of a licence-exempt transmitter outside any amateur radio allocations
A considerate operator does not transmit unnecessary signals
A courteous operator refrains from using offensive language
Questions.Explanation: Key words: NOT CORRECT. Using an amplifier on what is normally a license-exempt transmitter is illegal: e.g., a Citizens Band radio. Article 31 of the Radiocommunication Regulations states "A person may operate or permit the operation of radio apparatus only where the apparatus is maintained within the tolerances set out in the applicable standards". Article 32 of the Radiocommunication Regulations which said "A person may operate radio apparatus only to transmit a non-superfluous signal or a signal containing non-profane or non-obscene radiocommunications " was repealed in 2011 as inconsistent with the terms of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms.

Questions.Question: Which of the following statements is not correct?
Answers: An amateur radio operator transmitting unnecessary or offensive signals does not violate accepted practice

Except for a certified radio amateur operating within authorized amateur radio allocations, no person shall possess or operate any device for the purpose of amplifying the output power of a licence-exempt radio apparatus
A person may operate or permit the operation of radio apparatus only where the apparatus is maintained to the Radiocommunication Regulations tolerances
A person may operate an amateur radio station when the person complies with the Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service
Questions.Explanation: Article 32 of the Radiocommunication Regulations which said "A person may operate radio apparatus only to transmit a non-superfluous signal or a signal containing non-profane or non-obscene radiocommunications " was repealed in 2011 as inconsistent with the terms of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms. Hopefully, amateurs will continue to abide by that rule.

Questions.Question: Which of the following statements is not correct? A person may operate radio apparatus, authorized in the amateur service:
Answers: except for the amplification of the output power of licence-exempt radio apparatus operating outside authorized amateur radio service allocations
on aeronautical, marine or land mobile frequencies
only where the person complies with the Standards for the Operation of Radio Stations in the Amateur Radio Service
only where the apparatus is maintained within the performance standards set by Industry Canada regulations and policies
Questions.Explanation: Amateurs are only allowed on bands assigned to the Amateur service.

Questions.Question: Some VHF and UHF FM radios purchased for use in the amateur service can also be programmed to communicate on frequencies used for the land mobile service. Under what conditions is this permissible?
Answers: The equipment has a RF power output of 2 watts or less
The equipment is used in remote areas north of 60 degrees latitude
The radio is certified under the proper Radio Standard Specification for use in Canada and licensed by Industry Canada on the specified frequencies
The radio operator has a Restricted Operator's Certificate
Questions.Explanation: Article 31 of the Radiocommunication Regulations states "A person may operate or permit the operation of radio apparatus only where the apparatus is maintained within the tolerances set out in the applicable standards". The Radiocommunication Act states "4. (1) No person shall, except under and in accordance with a radio authorization, install, operate or possess radio apparatus, other than (a) radio apparatus exempted by or under regulations...".

Questions.Question: Which of the following cannot be discussed on an amateur club net?
Questions.Explanation: Business-related communications are NOT allowed on amateur bands (except for relief operations in a disaster while regular services are overloaded or unavailable).

Questions.Question: When is a radio amateur allowed to broadcast information to the general public?
Answers: Only when broadcasts last less than 1 hour
Only when broadcasts last longer than 15 minutes
Only when the operator is being paid
Questions.Explanation: Amateurs are not allowed to broadcast to the general public.

Questions.Question: When may false or deceptive amateur signals or communications be transmitted?
Answers: When you need to hide the meaning of a message for secrecy
When operating a beacon transmitter in a "fox hunt" exercise
Questions.Explanation: False or fraudulent messages or distress signals are infractions to the Radiocommunications Act.

Questions.Question: Which of the following one-way communications may not be transmitted in the amateur service?
Answers: Broadcasts intended for the general public
Radio control commands to model craft
Brief transmissions to make adjustments to the station
Questions.Explanation: Amateurs are not allowed to broadcast to the general public. Remote-Control, brief tests and code practice are allowed activities.

Questions.Question: You wish to develop and use a new digital encoding technique to transmit data over amateur radio spectrum. Under what conditions is this permissible?
Answers: When it is used for commercial traffic
When it includes sending the amateur station's call sign
When the encoding technique is published in the public domain
When it is used for music streaming content
Questions.Explanation: Article 47 of the Radiocommunication Regulations states "A person who operates radio apparatus in the amateur radio service may only (b) use a code or cipher that is not secret".

Questions.Question: When may an amateur station in two-way communication transmit an encoded message?
Answers: Only when the encoding or cipher is not secret
Questions.Explanation: Article 47 of the Radiocommunication Regulations states "A person who operates radio apparatus in the amateur radio service may only (b) use a code or cipher that is not secret".

Questions.Question: What are the restrictions on the use of abbreviations or procedural signals in the amateur service?
Answers: They are not permitted because they obscure the meaning of a message to government monitoring stations
They may be used if the signals or codes are not secret
Questions.Explanation: Specifically prohibited in the Radiocommunication Regulations.

Questions.Question: What should you do to keep you station from retransmitting music or signals from a non-amateur station?
Answers: Turn down the volume of background audio
Turn up the volume of your transmitter
Speak closer to the microphone to increase your signal strength
Questions.Explanation: Retransmitting programming that originates from a broadcasting undertaking is specifically prohibited in the Radiocommunication Regulations.

Questions.Question: The transmission of a secret code by the operator of an amateur station:
Answers: must be approved by Industry Canada
Questions.Explanation: Specifically prohibited in the Radiocommunication Regulations.

Questions.Question: A radio amateur may be engaged in communication which include the transmission of:
Answers: radiocommunication in support of industrial, business, or professional activities
programming that originates from a broadcasting undertaking
Questions.Explanation: Support of business/professional activities OR the retransmission of broadcasts are specifically prohibited in the Radiocommunication Regulations. "Q codes" are internationally recognized abbreviations used by Amateurs.

Questions.Question: In the amateur radio service, business communications:
Answers: are only permitted if they are for the safety of life or immediate protection of property
are not permitted under any circumstance
Questions.Explanation: Business-related communications are NOT allowed on amateur bands. RIC-3 states "47. A person who operates radio apparatus in the amateur radio service may only (c) be engaged in communication that does not include the transmission of i) music, (ii) commercially recorded material, (iii) programming that originates from a broadcasting undertaking, or (iv) radiocommunications in support of industrial, business or professional activities."  [ Until July 2007, RIC-7 seemed to make an exception for relief operations in a disaster while regular services are overloaded or unavailable. Prior to 2000, an amateur could communicate any message in a real or simulated emergency. ]

Questions.Question: Where may the holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate operate an amateur radio station in Canada?
Answers: Anywhere in Canada during times of emergency
Only at the address shown on Industry Canada records
Anywhere in your call sign prefix area
Questions.Explanation: Yes, ANYWHERE in Canada but if you change your address permanently, you must notify Industry Canada within 30 DAYS.

Questions.Question: Which type of station may transmit one-way communications?
Questions.Explanation: Only three types of one-way communications are allowed: 1) Beacons (automated one-way stations used to assess propagation conditions), 2) remote control of model craft and 3) brief test transmissions.

Questions.Question: Amateur radio operators may install or operate radio apparatus:
Answers: at the address which is on record at Industry Canada and at one other location
at the address which is on record at Industry Canada and in two mobiles
only at the address which is on record at Industry Canada
Questions.Explanation: Yes, ANYWHERE in Canada but if you change your address permanently, you must notify Industry Canada within 30 DAYS.

Questions.Question: In order to install any radio apparatus, to be used specifically for receiving and automatically retransmitting radiotelephone communications within the same frequency band, a radio amateur must hold an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate, with a minimum of:
Questions.Explanation: The Advanced Qualification grants 4 privileges: 1) install repeaters, 2) install club station, 3) build transmitters or amplifiers from scratch and 4) more output power.  Morse has nothing to do with such privileges.

Questions.Question: In order to install any radio apparatus, to be used specifically for an amateur radio club station, the radio amateur must hold an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate, with a minimum of the following qualifications:
Questions.Explanation: The Advanced Qualification grants 4 privileges: 1) install repeaters, 2) install club station, 3) build transmitters or amplifiers from scratch and 4) more output power.  Morse has nothing to do with such privileges.

Questions.Question: In order to install or operate a transmitter or RF amplifier that is neither professionally designed nor commercially manufactured for use in the amateur service, a radio amateur must hold an Amateur Operator's Certificate, with a minimum of which qualifications?
Questions.Explanation: "Advanced Qualification: all amateur bands below 30 MHz, transmitter power of 1000 watts DC input, build and operate transmitting equipment, establish repeaters and club stations. Basic Qualification: all amateur bands above 30 MHz, power of 250 watts DC input, build and operate all station equipment, except for "home-made" transmitters. "Build" in the context of the Basic Certificate is limited to the assembly of commercially available transmitter kits of professional design." (RIC-3, Privileges and Restrictions)

Questions.Question: Who is responsible for the proper operation of an amateur station?
Answers: The person who owns the station equipment
Both the control operator and the station owner
Only the station owner who is the holder of an Amateur Radio Operator Certificate
Questions.Explanation: Both the licensee and the control operator ( a person other than the licensee who the owner may have left in charge of the station ) are responsible for proper operation of the station.

Questions.Question: If you transmit from another amateur's station, who is responsible for its proper operation?
Answers: The station owner, unless the station records show that you were the control operator at the time
Questions.Explanation: Both the licensee and the control operator ( a person other than the licensee who the owner may have left in charge of the station ) are responsible for proper operation of the station.

Questions.Question: What is your responsibility as a station owner?
Answers: You are responsible for the proper operation of the station in accordance with the regulations
You must allow another amateur to operate your station upon request
You must be present whenever the station is operated
You must notify Industry Canada if another amateur acts as the control operator
Questions.Explanation: Both the licensee and the control operator ( a person other than the licensee who the owner may have left in charge of the station ) are responsible for proper operation of the station.

Questions.Question: Who may be the control operator of an amateur station?
Answers: Any qualified amateur chosen by the station owner
Any person over 21 years of age with a Basic Qualification
Any person over 21 years of age with Basic and Morse code qualifications
Any person over 21 years of age
Questions.Explanation: The Control Operator must hold an Amateur certificate.

Questions.Question: When must an amateur station have a control operator?
Answers: A control operator is not needed
Whenever the station receiver is operated
Questions.Explanation: The holder of an Amateur certificate, the 'Control Operator', must be in charge of the station whenever it is on the air.

Questions.Question: When an amateur station is transmitting, where must its control operator be?
Answers: Anywhere within 50 km of the station location
Anywhere in the same building as the transmitter
At the station's entrance, to control entry to the room
Questions.Explanation: The holder of an Amateur certificate, the 'Control Operator', must be in charge of the station whenever it is on the air.

Questions.Question: Why can't family members without qualifications transmit using your amateur station if they are alone with your equipment?
Answers: They must first know how to use the right abbreviations and Q signals
They must first know the right frequencies and emission modes for transmitting
They must hold suitable amateur radio qualifications before they are allowed to be control operators
They must not use your equipment without your permission
Questions.Explanation: The holder of an Amateur certificate, the 'Control Operator', must be in charge of the station whenever it is on the air. Your certificate does not grant spouse, siblings or relatives privileges to be 'Control Operators' ( i.e., use the station in your absence ).

Questions.Question: The owner of an amateur station may:
Answers: permit any person to operate the station under the supervision and in the presence of the holder of the amateur operator certificate
permit anyone to take part in communications only if prior written permission is received from Industry Canada
permit anyone to use the station without restrictions
permit anyone to use the station and take part in communications
Questions.Explanation: The holder of an Amateur certificate, the 'Control Operator', must be in charge of the station whenever it is on the air.

Questions.Question: Which of the following statements is correct?
Answers: Any person may operate an amateur station under supervision, and in the presence of, a person holding appropriate qualifications
A person, holding only Basic Qualification, may operate another station on 14.2 MHz
Radio amateurs may permit any person to operate the station without supervision
Any person may operate a station in the amateur radio service
Questions.Explanation: A Basic Qualification alone does not grant privileges below 30 MHz. A 'Control Operator' must hold an amateur certificate and supervise the station.

Questions.Question: What is a transmission called that disturbs other communications?
Questions.Explanation: "Harmful Interference": "Adverse effect of electromagnetic energy...that endangers the use of a safety-related radiocommunication system... OR significantly degrades, or obstructs or repeatedly interrupts the use of radio apparatus or radio-sensitive equipment."  (Radiocommunication Act)

Questions.Question: When may you deliberately interfere with another station's communications?
Answers: Only if the station is operating illegally
Only if the station begins transmitting on a frequency you are using
You may expect, and cause, deliberate interference because it can't be helped during crowded band conditions
Questions.Explanation: Deliberate harmful interference is ALWAYS prohibited.

Questions.Question: If the regulations say that the amateur service is a secondary user of a frequency band, and another service is a primary user, what does this mean?
Answers: Amateurs must increase transmitter power to overcome any interference caused by primary users
Amateurs are allowed to use the frequency band only if they do not cause interference to primary users
Nothing special: all users of a frequency band have equal rights to operate
Amateurs are only allowed to use the frequency band during emergencies
Questions.Explanation: Primary User and Secondary User are statuses assigned to different services when frequency bands are allocated by Industry Canada. "Stations of a secondary service: a) shall not cause harmful interference to stations of primary service, b) cannot claim protection from harmful interference from stations of a primary service". For Radiople, on 430-450 MHz and 902-928 MHz, the Amateur Radio Service has secondary status behind other services.

Questions.Question: What rule applies if two amateurs want to use the same frequency?
Answers: Station operators in ITU Regions 1 and 3 must yield the frequency to stations in ITU Region 2
Both station operators have an equal right to operate on the frequency
The station operator with a lesser qualification must yield the frequency to an operator of higher qualification
The station operator with a lower power output must yield the frequency to the station with a higher power output
Questions.Explanation: Common-sense and respect are expected out of amateurs in sharing radio spectrum. No organization, qualification or activity can claim exclusive and priority use of a given frequency.

Questions.Question: What name is given to a form of interference that seriously degrades, obstructs or repeatedly interrupts a radiocommunication service?
Questions.Explanation: "Harmful Interference": "Adverse effect of electromagnetic energy...that endangers the use of a safety-related radiocommunication system... OR significantly degrades, or obstructs or repeatedly interrupts the use of radio apparatus or radio-sensitive equipment."  (Radiocommunication Act)

Questions.Question: Where interference to the reception of radiocommunications is caused by the operation of an amateur station:
Answers: the Minister may require that the necessary steps for the prevention of the interference be taken by the radio amateur
the amateur station operator is not obligated to take any action
the amateur station operator may continue to operate without restrictions
the amateur station operator may continue to operate and the necessary steps can be taken when the amateur operator can afford it
Questions.Explanation: "The Department shall order the persons in control of the equipment to cease or modify operation until such time it can be operated without causing interference". (Radiocommunication Regulations)

Questions.Question: Radio amateur operation must not cause interference to other radio services operating in which of the following bands?
Questions.Explanation: Primary User and Secondary User are statuses assigned to different services when frequency bands are allocated by Industry Canada. "Stations of a secondary service: a) shall not cause harmful interference to stations of primary service, b) cannot claim protection from harmful interference from stations of a primary service". For Radiople, on 430-450 MHz and 902-928 MHz, the Amateur Radio Service has secondary status behind other services.

Questions.Question: Radio amateur operations are not ARE NOT protected from interference caused by another service operating in which of the following frequency bands?
Questions.Explanation: Primary User and Secondary User are statuses assigned to different services when frequency bands are allocated by Industry Canada. "Stations of a secondary service: a) shall not cause harmful interference to stations of primary service, b) cannot claim protection from harmful interference from stations of a primary service". For Radiople, on 430-450 MHz and 902-928 MHz, the Amateur Radio Service has secondary status behind other services.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not correct? The operator of an amateur station:
Answers: shall not cause harmful interference to a station in another service which has primary use of that band
may conduct technical experiments using the station apparatus
may make trials or tests, except if there is a possibility of interference to other stations
may make trials or tests, even though there is a possibility of interfering with other stations
Questions.Explanation: Conducting tests which may result in 'harmful interference' is prohibited.

Questions.Question: Which of these amateur bands may be heavily occupied by licence exempt devices?
Questions.Explanation: 135.7 to 137.8 kHz Fixed (primary), Maritime mobile (primary), Amateur (secondary). 3.5 to 4.0 MHz Amateur (primary). 144 to 148 MHz Amateur (primary). 430 to 450 MHz Radiolocation (primary), Amateur (secondary). 902 to 928 MHz Fixed (primary), Radiolocation (primary), Amateur (secondary), also designated for industrial, scientific and medical (ISM) applications. 1240 to 1300 MHz Radiolocation (primary), Amateur (secondary). 2300 to 2450 MHz Fixed (primary), Radiolocation (primary), Amateur (secondary), also designated for industrial, scientific and medical (ISM) applications. (Canadian Table of Frequency Allocations)

Questions.Question: The amateur radio service is authorized to share a portion of what Industrial Scientific Medical (ISM) band that is heavily used by licence exempt devices?
Questions.Explanation: 135.7 to 137.8 kHz Fixed (primary), Maritime mobile (primary), Amateur (secondary). 3.5 to 4.0 MHz Amateur (primary). 144 to 148 MHz Amateur (primary). 430 to 450 MHz Radiolocation (primary), Amateur (secondary). 902 to 928 MHz Fixed (primary), Radiolocation (primary), Amateur (secondary), also designated for industrial, scientific and medical (ISM) applications. 1240 to 1300 MHz Radiolocation (primary), Amateur (secondary). 2300 to 2450 MHz Fixed (primary), Radiolocation (primary), Amateur (secondary), also designated for industrial, scientific and medical (ISM) applications. (Canadian Table of Frequency Allocations)

Questions.Question: Amateur radio stations may communicate:
Answers: with any station involved in a real or simulated emergency
with anyone who uses international Morse code
Questions.Explanation: Article 47 of the Radiocommunication Regulations states "A person who operates radio apparatus in the amateur radio service may only (a) communicate with a radio station that operates in the amateur radio service". Article 48 further states "In a real or simulated emergency, a person operating radio apparatus in the amateur radio service may only communicate with a radio station that is in the amateur radio service in order to transmit a message that relates to the real or simulated emergency on behalf of a person, government or relief organization". A notice published in February 2000 invalidated this statement "In a real or simulated emergency, the operator of an amateur station may communicate any message that relates to that emergency on behalf of any person, government or relief organization".

Questions.Question: During relief operations in the days following a disaster, when may an amateur use his equipment to communicate on frequencies outside amateur bands?
Answers: When relaying messages on behalf of government agencies
When messages are destined to agencies without amateur radio support
When normal communication systems are overloaded, damaged or disrupted
Questions.Explanation: "An operator of an amateur station may operate within the frequency bands set out in the attached Schedules I, II and III in accordance with the operator's qualifications identified for the specified band". (RBR-4, Frequency Bands and Qualifications)

Questions.Question: If you hear an unanswered distress signal on an amateur band where you do not have privileges to communicate:
Answers: you may offer assistance after contacting Industry Canada for permission to do so
you may offer assistance using international Morse code only
Questions.Explanation: You may exceed your normal privileges to help a station in distress.

Questions.Question: In the amateur radio service, it is permissible to broadcast:
Answers: programming that originates from a broadcast undertaking
radio communications required for the immediate safety of life of individuals or the immediate protection of property
Questions.Explanation: Music, commercially recorded material and broadcasts are not permitted. Amateur radio can be used for distress communications.

Questions.Question: An amateur radio station in distress may:
Answers: only use radiocommunication bands for which the operator is qualified to use
use any means of radiocommunication, but only on internationally recognized emergency channels
only Morse code communications on internationally recognized emergency channels
Questions.Explanation: You may exceed your normal privileges if you are in distress.

Questions.Question: During a disaster, when may an amateur station make transmissions necessary to meet essential communication needs and assist relief operations?
Answers: Never: only official emergency stations may transmit in a disaster
When normal communication systems are working but are not convenient
Only when the local emergency net is activated
When normal communication systems are overloaded, damaged or disrupted
Questions.Explanation: Amateurs have a long history of handling communication when normal systems (e.g., telephone) are unavailable. When communications systems are restored, amateurs must return to the "no business" rule.

Questions.Question: During an emergency, what power output limitations must be observed by a station in distress?
Answers: There are no limitations for a station in distress
1000 watts PEP during daylight hours, reduced to 200 watts PEP during the night
Questions.Explanation: You may exceed your normal privileges if you are in distress.

Questions.Question: During a disaster:
Answers: use any United Nations approved frequency

most communications are handled by nets using predetermined frequencies in amateur bands. Operators not directly involved with disaster communications are requested to avoid making unnecessary transmissions on or near frequencies being used for disaster communications
use only frequencies in the 80 metre band
use only frequencies in the 40 metre band
Questions.Explanation: A 'net' (short for network) is a time and frequency where a given activity is conducted. Traffic is directed by a 'net control station'.

Questions.Question: Messages from recognized public service agencies may be handled by amateur radio stations:
Answers: during peace time and civil emergencies and exercises
when Industry Canada has issued a special authorization
only on the 7 and 14 MHz bands
Questions.Explanation: Messages from organizations such as the Red Cross or Civil Protection can be handled by amateurs at all times.

Questions.Question: It is permissible to interfere with the working of another station if:
Answers: you both wish to contact the same station
the other station is interfering with your transmission
your station is directly involved with a distress situation
the other station is not operating according to the Radiocommunication Regulations
Questions.Explanation: This is the only acceptable excuse for interference.

Questions.Question: What kind of payment is allowed for third-party messages sent by an amateur station?
Answers: No payment of any kind is allowed
Any amount agreed upon in advance
Questions.Explanation: "A person who operates in the Amateur Radio service shall do so without demanding or accepting remuneration in any form". (Radiocommunication Regulations)

Questions.Question: Radiocommunications transmitted by stations other than a broadcasting station may be divulged or used:
Answers: if it is transmitted by an amateur station
if transmitted by any station using the international Morse code
if transmitted in English or French
Questions.Explanation: "No person shall make use of  or  divulge a radio-based communication" except if it originates from a broadcaster ( e.g., the CBC) or an Amateur Radio station. (Radiocommunication Act)

Questions.Question: The operator of an amateur station:
Answers: may accept a gift or gratuity in lieu of remuneration for any message that the person transmits or receives
shall not demand or accept remuneration in any form, in respect of a radiocommunication that the person transmits or receives
shall charge no less than $10 for each message that the person transmits or receives
shall charge no more than $10 for each message that the person transmits or receives
Questions.Explanation: "A person who operates in the Amateur Radio service shall do so without demanding or accepting remuneration in any form". (Radiocommunication Regulations)

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not an exception from the penalties under the Act, for divulging, intercepting or using information obtained through radiocommunication, other than broadcasting?
Answers: Where it is for the purpose of preserving or protecting property, or for the prevention of harm to a person
Where it is for the purpose of giving evidence in a criminal or civil proceeding in which persons are required to give evidence
Where it is on behalf of Canada, for the purpose of international or national defence or security
Where it is to provide information for a journalist
Questions.Explanation: Protecting property, preventing harm, giving evidence and national security are valid exceptions to the privacy of communications.

Any language of a country which is a member of the International Telecommunication Union

at intervals not greater than ten minutes when using Morse code
when requested to do so by the station being called

Questions.Explanation: A reduction at the transmitting station from 1500 watts to 150 watts is a drop of -10 dB (one tenth). The received signal strength which read '10 dB OVER Nine S units' will drop -10 dB to simply 'Nine S units'.

Questions.Explanation: A reduction at the transmitting station from 1500 watts to 150 watts is a drop of -10 dB (one tenth). The received signal strength which reads '20 dB OVER Nine S units' will drop -10 dB to simply '10 dB over Nine S units'.

Questions.Question: What connects your transceiver to your antenna?
Questions.Explanation: A "transmission line" carries radio frequency signals from the station to the antenna and between the various pieces of equipment in the station.

Questions.Question: The characteristic impedance of a transmission line is determined by the:
Answers: frequency at which the line is operated
physical dimensions and relative positions of the conductors
Questions.Explanation: Characteristic Impedance is determined by the physical dimensions of the line. Length, frequency or load have nothing to do with it.

Questions.Question: The characteristic impedance of a 20 metre piece of transmission line is 52 ohms. If 10 metres were cut off, the impedance would be:
Questions.Explanation: This is a catch. Characteristic Impedance does NOT change with line length. Length, frequency or load have nothing to do with it.

Questions.Question: The characteristic impedance of a coaxial line:
Answers: can be the same for different diameter line
changes significantly with the frequency of the energy it carries
is correct for only one size of line
is greater for larger diameter line
Questions.Explanation: The Characteristic Impedance of coaxial cable is determined by the ratio of the outer conductor to the inner conductor. Different diameters of lines can have the same Characteristic Impedance as long as the RATIO is preserved.

Questions.Question: What commonly available antenna transmission line can be buried directly in the ground for some distance without adverse effects?
Questions.Explanation: Because the outer conductor of a coaxial cable is operated at ground potential, it can be buried. Parallel lines operate differently with both conductors at some voltage above ground.

Questions.Question: The characteristic impedance of a transmission line is:
Answers: the dynamic impedance of the line at the operating frequency
the ratio of the power supplied to the line to the power delivered to the load
equal to the pure resistance which, if connected to the end of the line, will absorb all the power arriving along it
the impedance of a section of the line one wavelength long
Questions.Explanation: If a resistor of the same value as the Characteristic Impedance of a given line is placed at the end of that line, no energy is reflected. 100% of the incoming energy is dissipated in the terminating load.

Questions.Question: A transmission line differs from an ordinary circuit or network in communications or signalling devices in one very important way. That important aspect is:
Questions.Explanation: Radio signals propagate (travel) slower in a transmission line than they do in space. 'Propagation Delay' is specific to transmission lines. Resistance and reactance can be found in many other components or circuits.

Questions.Question: The characteristic impedance of a parallel wire transmission line does not depend on the:
Answers: centre to centre distance between conductors
velocity of energy on the line
Questions.Explanation: Key words: DOES NOT. Physical dimensions (radius and centre to centre distance) and dielectric influence Characteristic Impedance. The speed at which waves travel on the line (velocity) is another characteristic altogether.

Questions.Question: If the impedance terminating a transmission line differs significantly from the characteristic impedance of the line, what will be observed at the input of the line?
Answers: An impedance nearly equal to the characteristic impedance
Some value of impedance influenced by line length
Questions.Explanation: A transmission line offers an input impedance similar to the terminating impedance when the impedance placed at the end of the line matches the characteristic impedance of the line: in short, a 50 ohms impedance at the end of a line with a characteristic impedance of 50 ohms will present a 50 ohms impedance to the transmitter, regardless of line length. If the terminating impedance is mismatched, the impedance seen at the input of the line will depend on terminating impedance AND line length: the line acts as an impedance transformer.

Questions.Question: What factors determine the characteristic impedance of a parallel-conductor antenna transmission line?
Answers: The radius of the conductors and the frequency of the signal
The frequency of the signal and the length of the line
The distance between the centres of the conductors and the radius of the conductors
The distance between the centres of the conductors and the length of the line
Questions.Explanation: Physical dimensions (radius and centre to centre distance) influence Characteristic Impedance. It is independent of line length or operating frequency.

Questions.Question: What factors determine the characteristic impedance of a coaxial antenna transmission line?
Answers: The diameter of the shield and the length of the line
The diameter of the shield and the frequency of the signal
The frequency of the signal and the length of the line
The ratio of the diameter of the inner conductor to the diameter of the outer shield
Questions.Explanation: The Characteristic Impedance of coaxial cable is determined by the ratio of the outer conductor to the inner conductor. It is independent of line length or operating frequency.

Questions.Question: What is a coaxial cable?
Answers: Two wires twisted around each other in a spiral
A center wire inside an insulating material which is covered by a metal sleeve or shield
Two wires side-by-side in a plastic ribbon
Two wires side-by-side held apart by insulating rods
Questions.Explanation: Coaxial: two concentric conductors, an inner conductor, a dielectric (insulator) and an outer conductor (braided or solid). 'Twin lead' (a type of parallel line) looks like a ribbon. 'Open wire line' or 'ladder line' (a type of parallel line) uses insulating rods. [ 'Twisted pair' is very rarely used in radio work. ]

Questions.Question: What is parallel-conductor transmission line?
Answers: Two wires twisted around each other in a spiral
A center wire inside an insulating material which is covered by a metal sleeve or shield
A metal pipe which is as wide or slightly wider than a wavelength of the signal it carries
Two wires side-by-side held apart by insulating material
Questions.Explanation: "Two wires held apart by insulating rods (spacers or 'spreaders')" is also known as 'open wire line' or 'ladder line'.

Questions.Question: What kind of antenna transmission line is made of two conductors held apart by insulated rods?
Answers: Twin lead in a plastic ribbon
Questions.Explanation: "Two wires held apart by insulating rods (spacers or 'spreaders')" is also known as 'open wire line' or 'ladder line'.

Questions.Question: What does the term "balun" mean?
Questions.Explanation: "Balun" is the contraction of "BALanced to UNbalanced". Dipole antennas and parallel lines operate in a BALanced mode (two conductors float above ground potential). A quarter-wave antenna, a ground-plane antenna and coaxial cable operate in an UNbalanced mode (with one side grounded). A BALUN interfaces balanced antenna to unbalanced transmission line  OR  balanced line to unbalanced line. A BALUN can also include impedance transformation.

Questions.Question: Where would you install a balun to feed a dipole antenna with 50-ohm coaxial cable?
Answers: Between the antenna and the ground
Between the coaxial cable and the ground
Between the coaxial cable and the antenna
Between the transmitter and the coaxial cable
Questions.Explanation: "Balun" is the contraction of "BALanced to UNbalanced". Dipole antennas and parallel lines operate in a BALanced mode (two conductors float above ground potential. A quarter-wave antenna, a ground-plane antenna and coaxial cable operate in an UNbalanced mode (with one side grounded). A BALUN interfaces balanced antenna to unbalanced transmission line  OR  balanced line to unbalanced line. A BALUN can also include impedance transformation.

Questions.Question: What is an unbalanced line?
Answers: Transmission line with both conductors connected to each other
Transmission line with one conductor connected to ground
Transmission line with neither conductor connected to ground
Transmission line with both conductors connected to ground
Questions.Explanation: An 'UNbalanced' transmission line functions with one conductor connected to ground (like coaxial cable or 'coax' for short). A 'balanced' transmission line operates with both conductors floating above ground potential (like all types of parallel lines: twin-lead, open-wire line).

Questions.Question: What device can be installed to feed a balanced antenna with an unbalanced transmission line?
Questions.Explanation: "Balun" is the contraction of "BALanced to UNbalanced". Dipole antennas and parallel lines operate in a BALanced mode (two conductors float above ground potential. A quarter-wave antenna, a ground-plane antenna and coaxial cable operate in an UNbalanced mode (with one side grounded). A BALUN interfaces balanced antenna to unbalanced transmission line  OR  balanced line to unbalanced line. A BALUN can also include impedance transformation.

Questions.Question: A flexible coaxial line contains:
Answers: four or more conductors running parallel
two parallel conductors separated by spacers
braided shield conductor and insulation around a central conductor
Questions.Explanation: Coaxial: two concentric conductors, an inner conductor, a dielectric (insulator) and an outer conductor (braided or solid). "Two parallel conductors separated by spacers" are also known as 'open wire line' or 'ladder line'.

Questions.Question: A balanced transmission line:
Answers: carries RF current on one wire only
is made of one conductor only
is made of two parallel wires
has one conductor inside the other
Questions.Explanation: A 'balanced' transmission line operates with both conductors floating above ground potential (like all types of parallel lines: twin-lead, open-wire line). An 'UNbalanced' transmission line functions with one conductor connected to ground (like coaxial cable or 'coax' for short).

Questions.Question: A 75 ohm transmission line could be matched to the 300 ohm feed point of an antenna:
Answers: by inserting a diode in one leg of the antenna
by using a 4 to 1 impedance transformer
Questions.Explanation: "Balun" is the contraction of "BALanced to UNbalanced". Dipole antennas and parallel lines operate in a BALanced mode (two conductors float above ground potential. A quarter-wave antenna, a ground-plane antenna and coaxial cable operate in an UNbalanced mode (with one side grounded). A BALUN interfaces balanced antenna to unbalanced transmission line  OR  balanced line to unbalanced line. A BALUN can also include impedance transformation. In this Radiople, a '4 to 1' balun.

Questions.Question: What kind of antenna transmission line can be constructed using two conductors which are maintained a uniform distance apart using insulated spreaders?
Questions.Explanation: "Two wires held apart by insulating rods (spacers or 'spreaders')" is also known as 'open wire line' or 'ladder line'. 'Twin-lead' is two conductors held apart in a plastic ribbon. Coaxial cable is two concentric conductors, an inner conductor, a dielectric (insulator) and an outer conductor (braided or solid).

Questions.Question: Why does coaxial cable make a good antenna transmission line?
Answers: It is weatherproof, and its impedance matches most amateur antennas
It is weatherproof, and its impedance is higher than that of most amateur antennas
It can be used near metal objects, and its impedance is higher than that of most amateur antennas
You can make it at home, and its impedance matches most amateur antennas
Questions.Explanation: Parallel lines generally have Characteristic Impedances in the range of 300 to 600 ohms. Common coaxial cable have Characteristic Impedances of 50 or 75 ohms. Such an impedance is a direct match to transmitters and common antennas.

Questions.Question: What is the best antenna transmission line to use, if it must be put near grounded metal objects?
Questions.Explanation: Coaxial cable, with its shielded and grounded outer conductor, is not affected by nearby metallic objects.

Questions.Question: What are some reasons not to use parallel-conductor transmission line?
Answers: It does not work well when tied down to metal objects, and you should use a balun and may have to use an impedance-matching device with your transceiver
You must use an impedance-matching device with your transceiver, and it does not work very well with a high SWR
It does not work well when tied down to metal objects, and it cannot operate under high power
It is difficult to make at home, and it does not work very well with a high SWR
Questions.Explanation: The high Characteristic Impedances and greater separation of the conductors in parallel lines DO permit high power and high Standing Wave Ratio (SWR)  BUT  nearby metallic objects can affect them and impedance matching is most often necessary at the transmitter end. Their high Characteristic Impedance permits carrying power with less current (P = R * I squared), less current implies less losses due to resistance.

Questions.Question: What common connector type usually joins RG-213 coaxial cable to an HF transceiver?
Questions.Explanation: 'RG-213' is the catalogue designation of common 10 mm (0.405 in.) coaxial cable. 'PL-259' is the catalogue designation of the male connector which matches the output connector found on MF/HF (Medium Frequency/High Frequency) transceivers. The 'SMA' connector is found on modern compact handheld transceivers. The 'Type-N' connector is the connector of choice above 300 MHz. The 'BNC' connector is found on larger size handheld transceivers.

Questions.Question: What common connector usually joins a hand-held transceiver to its antenna?
Questions.Explanation: The 'SMA' connector is found on modern compact handheld transceivers. The 'BNC' connector is found on older and larger handheld transceivers. 'PL-259' is the catalogue designation of the male connector which matches the output connector found on MF/HF (Medium Frequency/High Frequency) transceivers. The PL-259 connector fits on 10 mm (0.405 in.) coaxial cable such as RG-213. The 'Type-N' connector is the connector of choice above 300 MHz.

Questions.Question: Which of these common connectors has the lowest loss at UHF?
Questions.Explanation: The 'Type-N' connector is the connector of choice above 300 MHz. The 'BNC' connector is found on larger size handheld transceivers. 'PL-259' is the catalogue designation of the male connector which matches the output connector found on MF/HF (Medium Frequency/High Frequency) transceivers. The 'SMA' connector is found on modern compact handheld transceivers.

Questions.Question: If you install a 6 metre Yagi on a tower 60 metres (200 ft) from your transmitter, which of the following transmission lines provides the least loss?
Questions.Explanation: 'RG-213' is the coaxial with the largest diameter (10 mm or 0.405 in.) in this group. It has the lowest loss per 30 m length.

Questions.Question: Why should you regularly clean and tighten all antenna connectors?
Answers: To help keep their contact resistance at a minimum
To keep them from getting stuck in place
Questions.Explanation: Poor connections can also lead to intermittent electrical contact (evidenced by an erratic or 'jumpy' Standing Wave Ratio (SWR) reading at the station).

Questions.Question: What commonly available antenna transmission line can be buried directly in the ground for some distance without adverse effects?
Questions.Explanation: Coaxial cable, with its shielded and grounded outer conductor, is not affected by conductive soil. It is also not affected by nearby metallic objects.

Questions.Question: When antenna transmission lines must be placed near grounded metal objects, which of the following transmission lines should be used?
Questions.Explanation: Coaxial cable, with its grounded outer conductor, is not affected by nearby metallic objects.

Questions.Question: TV twin-lead transmission line can be used for a transmission line in an amateur station. The impedance of this line is approximately:
Questions.Explanation: 50 ohms is the common Characteristic Impedance of coaxial cable. 600 ohms is the common Characteristic Impedance of 'open-wire line' (a.k.a. ladder line). 300 ohms is the Characteristic Impedance of twin-lead transmission line used with yesteryear outside television antennas.

Questions.Question: Why should you use only good quality coaxial cable and connectors for a UHF antenna system?
Answers: To keep the power going to your antenna system from getting too high
To keep the standing wave ratio of your antenna system high
Questions.Explanation: Losses in transmission lines increase with length and operating frequencies. At Ultra High Frequencies (UHF, 300 MHz to 3000 MHz), keeping losses low is paramount.

Questions.Question: What are some reasons to use parallel-conductor transmission line?
Answers: It has low impedance, and will operate with a high SWR
It will operate with a high SWR, and it works well when tied down to metal objects
It has a low impedance, and has less loss than coaxial cable
It will operate with a high SWR, and has less loss than coaxial cable
Questions.Explanation: The high Characteristic Impedances and greater separation of the conductors in parallel lines DO permit high power and high Standing Wave Ratio (SWR)  BUT  nearby metallic objects can affect them and impedance matching is most often necessary at the transmitter end. Their high Characteristic Impedance permits carrying power with less current (P = R * I squared), less current implies less losses due to resistance.

Questions.Question: If your transmitter and antenna are 15 metres (50 ft) apart, but are connected by 60 metres (200 ft) of RG-58 coaxial cable, what should be done to reduce transmission line loss?
Answers: Roll the excess cable into a coil which is as small as possible
Shorten the excess cable so the transmission line is an even number of wavelengths long
Shorten the excess cable so the transmission line is an odd number of wavelengths long
Questions.Explanation: Forty-five extra metres (150 ft.) of unnecessary RG-58 (diameter = 5 mm or 0.195 in.) introduce 4 dB of loss at 30 MHz, that's the problem here. [ References to multiples of the wavelength only tap into urban legends. ]

Questions.Question: As the length of a transmission line is changed, what happens to signal loss?
Answers: Signal loss is the same for any length of transmission line
Signal loss increases as length increases
Signal loss decreases as length increases
Signal loss is the least when the length is the same as the signal's wavelength
Questions.Explanation: Signal loss in a given transmission line AUGMENT with increased length or increased operating frequency. For Radiople, 30 m of RG-58 introduce a loss of -3 dB at 50 MHz. Doubling the length, double the loss: 60 m of RG-58 lose -6 dB at 50 MHz. The original 30 m of RG-58 wastes -10 dB at 450 MHz.

Questions.Question: As the frequency of a signal is changed, what happens to signal loss in a transmission line?
Answers: Signal loss is the least when the signal's wavelength is the same as the transmission line's length
Signal loss is the same for any frequency
Signal loss increases with increasing frequency
Signal loss increases with decreasing frequency
Questions.Explanation: Signal loss in a given transmission line AUGMENT with increased length or increased operating frequency. For Radiople, 30 m of RG-58 introduce a loss of -3 dB at 50 MHz. Doubling the length, double the loss: 60 m of RG-58 lose -6 dB at 50 MHz. The original 30 m of RG-58 wastes -10 dB at 450 MHz.

Questions.Question: Losses occurring on a transmission line between transmitter and antenna results in:
Questions.Explanation: Losses in the line are merely transmit energy that does not get to the antenna to be radiated  OR  received signal which does not reach the receiver to be detected. The SWR reading is primarily dependent on the adequacy of the match between the load placed at the end of the line and the Characteristic Impedance of the line. Reflections, measured by SWR, are caused by an improper match at the end of the line.

Questions.Question: The lowest loss transmission line on HF is:
Questions.Explanation: 300 ohms is the Characteristic Impedance of TV twin-lead transmission line. The high Characteristic Impedances and greater separation of the conductors in parallel lines DO permit high power and high Standing Wave Ratio (SWR)  BUT  nearby metallic objects can affect them and impedance matching is most often necessary at the transmitter end. Their high Characteristic Impedance permits carrying power with less current (P = R * I squared), less current implies less losses due to resistance.

Questions.Question: In what values are RF transmission line losses expressed?
Questions.Explanation: "Decibels per unit length". In North America, typically 'dB per 100 ft.' or 'dB per 30 m' at a given frequency. Loss rises proportionally with length. Loss goes up as frequency goes up.

Questions.Question: If the length of coaxial transmission line is increased from 20 metres (66 ft) to 40 metres (132 ft), how would this affect the line loss?
Questions.Explanation: If line length is doubled, the incurred signal loss is doubled. Loss for transmission lines is specified as "decibels per 100 feet (30 m)" at a certain frequency. Signal loss in a given transmission line AUGMENT with increased length or increased operating frequency. For Radiople, 30 m of RG-58 introduce a loss of -3 dB at 50 MHz. Doubling the length, double the loss: 60 m of RG-58 lose -6 dB at 50 MHz. The original 30 m of RG-58 wastes -10 dB at 450 MHz.

Questions.Question: If the frequency is increased, how would this affect the loss on a transmission line?
Answers: It depends on the line length
Questions.Explanation: The higher the frequency, the higher the loss. Larger diameter coaxial cables are recommended at VHF (Very High Frequency) and UHF (Ultra High Frequency) to minimize losses. Signal loss in a given transmission line AUGMENT with increased length or increased operating frequency. For Radiople, 30 m of RG-58 introduce a loss of -3 dB at 50 MHz. Doubling the length, double the loss: 60 m of RG-58 lose -6 dB at 50 MHz. The original 30 m of RG-58 wastes -10 dB at 450 MHz.

Questions.Question: What does an SWR reading of 1:1 mean?
Answers: The best impedance match has been attained
An antenna for another frequency band is probably connected
No power is going to the antenna
Questions.Explanation: SWR is a measure of the impedance match in the antenna system. A Standing Wave Ratio (SWR) of '1 to 1' is an ideal condition indicating no reflected energy. The impedance of the load at the end of the transmission line matches the Characteristic Impedance of the line. Impedance Match has been achieved. A Standing Wave Ratio (SWR) of '1.5 to 1' would indicate a fairly good match while a very high SWR would indicate a short-circuit or an open-circuit somewhere along the transmission line.

Questions.Question: What does an SWR reading of less than 1.5:1 mean?
Answers: An impedance match which is too low
A serious impedance mismatch; something may be wrong with the antenna system
Questions.Explanation: SWR is a measure of the impedance match in the antenna system. A Standing Wave Ratio (SWR) of '1.5 to 1' is a totally acceptable condition indicating little reflected energy. A '1 to 1' ratio would indicate a perfect match while a very high SWR would indicate a short-circuit or an open-circuit somewhere along the transmission line.

Questions.Question: What kind of SWR reading may mean poor electrical contact between parts of an antenna system?
Questions.Explanation: SWR is a measure of the impedance match in the antenna system. A 'jumpy' (erratic) reading resulting from the sometimes on, sometimes off electrical contact would indicate a loose connection in the antenna system.

Questions.Question: What does a very high SWR reading mean?
Answers: The antenna is the wrong length for the operating frequency, or the transmission line may be open or short circuited
The transmitter is putting out more power than normal, showing that it is about to go bad
There is a large amount of solar radiation, which means very poor radio conditions
The signals coming from the antenna are unusually strong, which means very good radio condition
Questions.Explanation: SWR is a measure of the impedance match in the antenna system. A very high SWR, indicating that most if not all energy sent up the line is reflected back indicates that the antenna is cut for a totally different frequency  OR  that a short-circuit or open-circuit exists somewhere along the line.

Questions.Question: What does standing-wave ratio mean?
Answers: The ratio of maximum to minimum inductances on a transmission line
The ratio of maximum to minimum resistances on a transmission line
The ratio of maximum to minimum impedances on a transmission line
The ratio of maximum to minimum voltages on a transmission line
Questions.Explanation: 'Standing Waves' result from the interaction of the forward power sent from the transmitter towards the antenna  and  the reverse power reflected back by an improper impedance match. The interaction produces a repeating pattern of voltage peaks and troughs along the line. SWR is also known as 'Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR)': it is a measure of the peak voltage to the minimum voltage on the standing wave.

Questions.Question: If your antenna transmission line gets hot when you are transmitting, what might this mean?
Answers: You should transmit using less power
The conductors in the transmission line are not insulated very well
The transmission line is too long
The SWR may be too high, or the transmission line loss may be high
Questions.Explanation: Line losses, possibly compounded by high Standing Wave Ratio (SWR), waste energy as heat.

Questions.Question: If the characteristic impedance of the transmission line does not match the antenna input impedance then:
Answers: the antenna will not radiate any signal
standing waves are produced in the transmission line
heat is produced at the junction
Questions.Explanation: 'Standing Waves' result from the interaction of the forward power sent from the transmitter towards the antenna  and  the reverse power reflected back by an improper impedance match. The interaction produces a repeating pattern of voltage peaks and troughs along the line. SWR is also known as 'Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR)': it is a measure of the peak voltage to the minimum voltage on the standing wave.

Questions.Question: The result of the presence of standing waves on a transmission line is:
Answers: lack of radiation from the transmission line
reduced transfer of RF energy to the antenna
perfect impedance match between transmitter and transmission line
maximum transfer of energy to the antenna from the transmitter
Questions.Explanation: High SWR add to line losses and lead to energy wasted as heat.

Questions.Question: An SWR meter measures the degree of match between transmission line and antenna by:
Answers: inserting a diode in the transmission line
Questions.Explanation: 'Standing Waves' result from the interaction of the forward power sent from the transmitter towards the antenna  and  the reverse power reflected back by an improper impedance match. The interaction produces a repeating pattern of voltage peaks and troughs along the line. SWR is also known as 'Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR)': it is a measure of the peak voltage to the minimum voltage on the standing wave.

Questions.Question: A resonant antenna having a feed point impedance of 200 ohms is connected to a transmission line which has an impedance of 50 ohms. What will the standing wave ratio of this system be?
Questions.Explanation: A resonant antenna (reactances cancel each other at resonance) does not present any reactance (X) but only a 'radiation resistance'. In such a situation, SWR can be computed as the ratio of the impedances. In this Radiople, 200 / 50 yields a ratio of '4 to 1'. SWR is normally a ratio of maximum to minimum voltage on the standing wave.

Questions.Question: The type of transmission line best suited to operating at a high standing wave ratio is:
Questions.Explanation: The high Characteristic Impedances and greater separation of the conductors in parallel lines DO permit high power and high Standing Wave Ratio (SWR)  BUT  nearby metallic objects can affect them and impedance matching is most often necessary at the transmitter end. Their high Characteristic Impedance permits carrying power with less current (P = R * I squared), less current implies less losses due to resistance.

Questions.Question: What would you use to connect a coaxial cable of 50 ohms impedance to an antenna of 17 ohms impedance?
Questions.Explanation: The impedance mismatch could be corrected by an 'impedance-matching device'.

Questions.Question: To obtain efficient power transmission from a transmitter to an antenna requires:
Questions.Explanation: Impedance Match: maximum power transfer occurs when the impedance of the load matches the internal impedance of the source. For Radiople, A transmitter designed to work into an impedance of 50 ohms, will delivered maximum power if the antenna system offers an impedance of 50 ohms.

Questions.Question: To obtain efficient transfer of power from a transmitter to an antenna, it is important that there is a:
Questions.Explanation: Impedance Match: maximum power transfer occurs when the impedance of the load matches the internal impedance of the source. For Radiople, A transmitter designed to work into an impedance of 50 ohms, will delivered maximum power if the antenna system offers an impedance of 50 ohms.

Questions.Question: If an antenna is correctly matched to a transmitter, the length of transmission line:
Answers: must be a full wavelength long
must be an odd number of quarter-wave
must be an even number of half-waves
will have no effect on the matching
Questions.Explanation: IF a mismatch is present at the end of the transmission lines, certain lengths may introduce an 'impedance transformation' effect. With a correctly matched antenna, line length is immaterial except for line losses if the line is unnecessarily long. [ References to multiples of the wavelength only tap into urban legends. ]

Questions.Question: The reason that an RF transmission line should be matched at the transmitter end is to:
Answers: ensure that the radiated signal has the intended polarization
overcome fading of the transmitted signal
transfer the maximum amount of power to the antenna
Questions.Explanation: Impedance Match: maximum power transfer occurs when the impedance of the load matches the internal impedance of the source. For Radiople, A transmitter designed to work into an impedance of 50 ohms, will delivered maximum power if the antenna system offers an impedance of 50 ohms.

Questions.Question: If the centre impedance of a folded dipole is approximately 300 ohms, and you are using RG8U (50 ohms) coaxial lines, what is the ratio required to have the line and the antenna matched?
Questions.Explanation: Impedance transformation of 300 to 50 ohms is required. 300 / 50 = '6 to 1'.

Title: Active Devices: Diodes, Transistors and Tubes.

Questions.Question: A circuit designed to increase the level of its input signal is called:
Questions.Explanation: An amplifier reproduces its input signal into a larger output signal ( more voltage, more current, more power).

Questions.Question: If an amplifier becomes non-linear, the output signal would:
Questions.Explanation: If an amplifier is 'linear', amplification, as a ratio of output versus input, will be constant regardless of frequency or amplitude of the input signal. Linearity is synonym with 'absence of distortion'. 'Non-linear' implies distortion.

Questions.Question: To increase the level of very weak radio signals from an antenna, you would use:
Questions.Explanation: A radio frequency (RF) amplifier must be used.

Questions.Question: To increase the level of very weak signals from a microphone you would use:
Questions.Explanation: An 'audio amplifier'. Frequently called a 'speech amplifier' or 'microphone amplifier' for this particular application.

Questions.Question: The range of frequencies to be amplified by a speech amplifier is typically:
Questions.Explanation: Frequencies audible to humans range from 20 Hz to 20,000 Hz. Speech frequencies important for intelligibility in communications range from 300 Hz to 3000 Hz.

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not amplified by an amplifier?
Questions.Explanation: Amplifiers work on voltage, current and power.

Questions.Question: The increase in signal level by an amplifier is called:
Questions.Explanation: Gain (synonymous with amplification) is an increase in signal voltage/current/power. 'Attenuation' is a loss (opposite to gain). 'Amplitude' is the instantaneous value of a signal. 'Modulation' is the impression of a message onto another signal.

Questions.Question: A device with gain has the property of:
Questions.Explanation: Gain and Amplification are synonymous. 'Attenuation' is a loss (opposite to gain). 'Oscillation' is the production of an Alternating Current (AC) signal. 'Modulation' is the impression of a message onto another signal.

Questions.Question: A device labelled "Gain = 10 dB" is likely to be an:
Questions.Explanation: Gain and Amplification are synonymous. 'Attenuation' is a loss (opposite to gain). 'Oscillation' is the production of an Alternating Current (AC) signal. 'Modulation' is the impression of a message onto another signal.

Questions.Question: Amplifiers can amplify:
Questions.Explanation: Recall that Inductance, a property of coils, is influenced by "The core material, the core diameter, the length of the coil and the number of turns of wire used to wind the coil".

Questions.Question: Which of the following is not a property of an amplifier?
Questions.Explanation: Gain and Amplification are synonymous. Linearity (or lack of distortion) is a specification of amplifiers. Loss has nothing to do with amplifiers.

Questions.Question: Zener diodes are used as:
Questions.Explanation: ZENER diodes maintain a constant voltage across their terminals. Hence, they are used for voltage regulation.

Questions.Question: One important application for diodes is recovering information from transmitted signals. This is referred to as:
Questions.Explanation: Detection = DEmodulation = Recovery of the message carried on a radio signal.

Questions.Question: The primary purpose of a Zener diode is to:
Answers: to boost the power supply voltage
provide a path through which current can flow
regulate or maintain a constant voltage
Questions.Explanation: ZENER diodes maintain a constant voltage across their terminals. Hence, they are used for voltage regulation.

Questions.Question: The action of changing alternating current to direct current is called:
Questions.Explanation: Changing AC to DC is called 'Rectification'. AC is turned into 'pulsating DC' (it flows in one direction only) after going through a diode. In Power Supply circuits, diodes are called 'Rectifiers'. Diodes have two electrodes: Cathode and Anode. Electrons flow from Cathode to Anode in a forward-biased (i.e., a diode subjected to a voltage polarity which permits conduction) diode.

Questions.Question: The electrodes of a semiconductor diode are known as:
Questions.Explanation: A DIODE, vacuum tube or semiconductor, has two electrodes: Anode and Cathode. Electrons flow from Cathode to Anode in a forward-biased (i.e., a diode subjected to a voltage polarity which permits conduction) diode. Cathode/Grid/Anode(plate) are electrodes in a vacuum triode. Source/Gate/Drain are electrodes in a Field Effect Transistor (FET, N-Channel or P-Channel). Emitter/Base/Collector are electrodes in a Bipolar Transistor ( type PNP or NPN ).

Questions.Question: If alternating current is applied to the anode of a diode, what would you expect to see at the cathode?
Questions.Explanation: Changing AC to DC is called 'Rectification'. AC is turned into 'pulsating DC' (it flows in one direction only) after going through a diode. In Power Supply circuits, diodes are called 'Rectifiers'. Diodes have two electrodes: Cathode and Anode. Electrons flow from Cathode to Anode in a forward-biased (i.e., a diode subjected to a voltage polarity which permits conduction) diode.

Questions.Question: In a semiconductor diode, electrons flow from:
Questions.Explanation: A DIODE, vacuum tube or semiconductor, has two electrodes: Anode and Cathode. Electrons flow from Cathode to Anode in a forward-biased (i.e., a diode subjected to a voltage polarity which permits conduction) diode. Cathode/Grid/Anode(plate) are electrodes in a vacuum triode. Source/Gate/Drain are electrodes in a Field Effect Transistor (FET, N-Channel or P-Channel). Emitter/Base/Collector are electrodes in a Bipolar Transistor ( type PNP or NPN ).

Questions.Question: What semiconductor device glows different colours, depending upon its chemical composition?
Questions.Explanation: "LED", a Light-Emitting Diode.

Questions.Question: Voltage regulation is the principal application of the:
Questions.Explanation: ZENER diodes maintain a constant voltage across their terminals. Hence, they are used for voltage regulation.

Questions.Question: In order for a diode to conduct, it must be:
Questions.Explanation: A DIODE, vacuum tube or semiconductor, has two electrodes: Anode and Cathode. Electrons flow from Cathode to Anode in a forward-biased (i.e., a diode subjected to a voltage polarity which permits conduction) diode. Cathode/Grid/Anode(plate) are electrodes in a vacuum triode. Source/Gate/Drain are electrodes in a Field Effect Transistor (FET, N-Channel or P-Channel). Emitter/Base/Collector are electrodes in a Bipolar Transistor ( type PNP or NPN ).

Questions.Question: Which component can amplify a small signal using low voltages?
Questions.Explanation: A transistor amplifies signals and can work at a low voltage. Bipolar Transistors ( type PNP or NPN ) as well as Field Effect Transistor (FET, N-Channel or P-Channel) can amplify signals.

Questions.Question: The basic semiconductor amplifying device is the:
Questions.Explanation: A transistor amplifies signals. Bipolar Transistors ( type PNP or NPN ) as well as Field Effect Transistor (FET, N-Channel or P-Channel) can amplify signals. A 'single P-N junction' is a diode. Diodes have two main uses: 'Rectification' and 'Detection'.

Questions.Question: The three leads from a PNP transistor are named:
Questions.Explanation: Emitter/Base/Collector are electrodes in a Bipolar Transistor ( type PNP or NPN ). Source/Gate/Drain are electrodes in a Field Effect Transistor (FET, N-Channel or P-Channel). Cathode/Grid/Anode(plate) are electrodes in a vacuum triode.

Questions.Question: If a low level signal is placed at the input to a transistor, a higher level of signal is produced at the output lead. This effect is known as:
Questions.Explanation: Detection = DEmodulation = Recovery of the message carried on a radio signal. 'Modulation' is the impression of a message onto another signal. 'Rectification' turns AC into 'pulsating DC' (it flows in one direction only) after going through a diode.

Questions.Question: Bipolar transistors usually have:
Questions.Explanation: Emitter/Base/Collector are electrodes in a Bipolar Transistor ( type PNP or NPN ). Source/Gate/Drain are electrodes in a Field Effect Transistor (FET, N-Channel or P-Channel). Cathode/Grid/Anode(plate) are electrodes in a vacuum triode.

Questions.Question: A semiconductor is described as a "general purpose audio NPN device". This would be:
Questions.Explanation: The only choice in the group comprising a sandwich of N-semiconductor and P-semiconductor is the 'Bipolar Transistor'.

Questions.Question: The two basic types of bipolar transistors are:
Questions.Explanation: It is constructed with a sandwich of N-semiconductor and P-semiconductor: NPN or PNP type.

Questions.Question: A transistor can be destroyed in a circuit by:
Questions.Explanation: Extreme operating temperatures can rapidly destroy transistors.

Questions.Question: In a bipolar transistor, the _____________ compares closest to the control grid of a triode vacuum tube.
Questions.Explanation: Comparing Triode/Bipolar Transistor/FET in terms of their RESPECTIVE electrodes: Origin of charge carriers = Cathode/Emitter/Source. Control electrode = Grid/Base/Gate. Destination of charge carriers = Anode(plate)/Collector/Drain.

Questions.Question: In a bipolar transistor, the _____________ compares closest to the plate of a triode vacuum tube.
Questions.Explanation: Comparing Triode/Bipolar Transistor/FET in terms of their RESPECTIVE electrodes: Origin of charge carriers = Cathode/Emitter/Source. Control electrode = Grid/Base/Gate. Destination of charge carriers = Anode(plate)/Collector/Drain.

Questions.Question: In a bipolar transistor, the _____________ compares closest to the cathode of a triode vacuum tube.
Questions.Explanation: Comparing Triode/Bipolar Transistor/FET in terms of their RESPECTIVE electrodes: Origin of charge carriers = Cathode/Emitter/Source. Control electrode = Grid/Base/Gate. Destination of charge carriers = Anode(plate)/Collector/Drain.

Questions.Question: The two basic types of field effect transistors (FET) are:
Questions.Explanation: In a field effect transistor, Source and Drain are the two extremities of a 'channel' made of a single semi-conductor type. NPN and PNP are the two types of BIPOLAR Transistors.

Questions.Question: A semiconductor having its leads labelled gate, drain, and source is best described as a:
Questions.Explanation: Source/Gate/Drain are electrodes in a Field Effect Transistor (FET, N-Channel or P-Channel). Emitter/Base/Collector are electrodes in a Bipolar Transistor ( type PNP or NPN ). Cathode/Grid/Anode(plate) are electrodes in a vacuum triode.

Questions.Question: In a field effect transistor, the ___________ is the terminal that controls the conductance of the channel.
Questions.Explanation: Comparing Triode/Bipolar Transistor/FET in terms of their RESPECTIVE electrodes: Origin of charge carriers = Cathode/Emitter/Source. Control electrode = Grid/Base/Gate. Destination of charge carriers = Anode(plate)/Collector/Drain.

Questions.Question: In a field effect transistor, the ___________ is the terminal where the charge carriers enter the channel.
Questions.Explanation: Comparing Triode/Bipolar Transistor/FET in terms of their RESPECTIVE electrodes: Origin of charge carriers = Cathode/Emitter/Source. Control electrode = Grid/Base/Gate. Destination of charge carriers = Anode(plate)/Collector/Drain.

Questions.Question: In a field effect transistor, the ___________ is the terminal where the charge carriers leave the channel.
Questions.Explanation: Comparing Triode/Bipolar Transistor/FET in terms of their RESPECTIVE electrodes: Origin of charge carriers = Cathode/Emitter/Source. Control electrode = Grid/Base/Gate. Destination of charge carriers = Anode(plate)/Collector/Drain.

Questions.Question: Which semiconductor device has characteristics most similar to a triode vacuum tube?
Questions.Explanation: The triode and the FET both rely on a reverse voltage on their control electrodes to affect the current through the device.

Questions.Question: The control element in the field effect transistor is the:
Questions.Explanation: Comparing Triode/Bipolar Transistor/FET in terms of their RESPECTIVE electrodes: Origin of charge carriers = Cathode/Emitter/Source. Control electrode = Grid/Base/Gate. Destination of charge carriers = Anode(plate)/Collector/Drain.

Questions.Question: If you wish to reduce the current flowing in a field effect transistor, you could:
Questions.Explanation: The triode and the FET both rely on a reverse voltage on their control electrodes to affect the current through the device.

Questions.Question: The source of a field effect transistor corresponds to the _______ of a bipolar transistor.
Questions.Explanation: Comparing Triode/Bipolar Transistor/FET in terms of their RESPECTIVE electrodes: Origin of charge carriers = Cathode/Emitter/Source. Control electrode = Grid/Base/Gate. Destination of charge carriers = Anode(plate)/Collector/Drain.

Questions.Question: The drain of a field effect transistor corresponds to the _______ of a bipolar transistor.
Questions.Explanation: Comparing Triode/Bipolar Transistor/FET in terms of their RESPECTIVE electrodes: Origin of charge carriers = Cathode/Emitter/Source. Control electrode = Grid/Base/Gate. Destination of charge carriers = Anode(plate)/Collector/Drain.

Questions.Question: Which two elements in a field effect transistor exhibit fairly similar characteristics?
Questions.Explanation: Source and Drain are the two ends of the same block of semiconductor material, the 'Channel'. Only the control electrode, the Gate, is made of the opposite type of material.

Questions.Question: What is one reason a triode vacuum tube might be used instead of a transistor in a circuit?
Answers: It may be able to handle higher power
